story: Princess Eugenie will marry on Friday at St George&rsquos Chapel, Windsor (Image: Constant Media)Beau Jack Brooksbank chose the most glorious setting - the shores of the stunning Lake Nicaragua as the sun set over the monumental Concepcion volcano &ndash to go down on one knee.And as her romantic husband-to-be Mr Brooksbank popped the question in heart-melting fashion Princess Eugenie responded in textbook fashion by promptly bursting into tears.She said: The lake was so beautiful. The light was just a special light I had never seen.&ldquoI actually said this is an incredible moment, and then he popped the question, which was really surprising even though we have been together seven years.                Princess Eugenie wedding: Eugenie ALL SMILES arriving at Palace                Princes Eugenie wedding: Jack Brooksbank pays TRIBUTE to fianc&eacutee wi...I was over the moon.It was a complete surprise. But it was the perfect moment, we couldn't be happier.We met when I was 20 and Jack was 24 and fell in love, she said. We have the same passions and drive for life.The couple were on a romantic getaway to the volcano-dotted nation of Nicaragua known alternately both for the beauty of its rainforest countryside and the ugliness of its political history.They were staying on the island of Ometepe in the middle of Lake Nicaragua (AKA Cocibolca) which has Concepcion volcano to the north and Maderas volcano to the south.They had previously been on the ultra-exclusive tiny island of Calala, off Nicaragua&rsquos east coast.Eugenie said the proposal had come as a massive surprise &ndash despite the pair being a rock solid couple for almost a decade.Jack added: It was amazing. I love Eugenie so much and we are just so happy and over the moon for what is to come.The couple will marry on Friday at St George&rsquos Chapel, Windsor, the same venue as Prince Harry, her cousin, and Meghan Markle.Eugenie, 27, is the second daughter of Prince Andrew and Sarah, Duchess of York, and is eighth in line to the throne.She will keep her royal title when she marries Mr Brooksbank and will have the option to take his surname.The royal&rsquos holiday destination raised some eyebrows as Nicaragua has a troubled recent history.Current president Daniel Ortega helped lead the armed Sandinista struggle against the US-backed ruling powers throughout the 60s, 70s and 80s and is routinely cited by Amnesty International for violent suppression of political opposition.

title: Brexit news Andrew Neil Chuka Umunna Labour Party policy Corbyn latest
story: Andrew Neil, the BBC presenter, put Labour MP Chuka Umunna on the spot about the perceived failure of his party to come up with sustainable policies for Britain.Labour has been repeatedly accused of lacking clarity on its plans to address national issues such as Brexit &ndash with Labour MPs showcasing a disparity of opinions on the strategies the party should adopt during the withdrawal process from the European Union.The BBC This Week host voiced his doubts about Labour's ability to lure in new voters with its indecisive position to Mr Umunna: Labour politicians have been saying this to me, in this studio, it never comes down to any kind of policy that you can take forward.It would seem to me you have lost your party for a generation now. At least. What do you do?                Brexiteer shuts down Labour Lord calling for ANOTHER Brexit vote                 'No problem!' NO DEAL Brexit is solution to EU negotiations Mr Umunna did not attempt to propose a solution but concluded it's a question for the leadership to address. He, however, urged the party to return to its core values and focus on new work policies and love of your communities.The Streatham MP said: I don&rsquot know the answer to that question and ultimately I think it&rsquos a question for the leadership, it&rsquos not a question for me.Do they still want the social democratic centre-left tradition to be at the heart of the Labour Party or not? I&rsquom not the leader of the Labour Party, I don&rsquot get to decide that. I do think in terms of the fundamental core values of what it is to be a social democrat we have to return to.A YouGov poll of 1,628 Britons suggested 29 percent of voters find Labour's policies on Brexit fairly unclear or confusing, against 2 percent claiming their policies are very clear.Brexit news: Andrew Neil warned Labour they had lost the party for a generation  (Image: BBC)Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer said &ldquonobody is ruling out Remain as an option should there be another referendum on Britain&rsquos relationship with the EU, and claimed Labour would only back a deal that met all of the party&rsquos six tests.But addressing delegates at the Labour Party Conference in September, Jeremy Corbyn insisted his party will not try to overturn the results of the 2016 referendum.Mr Corbyn said: &ldquoLabour respects the decision of the British people in the referendum but no one can respect the conduct of the government since that vote took place.As it stands, Labour will vote against the Chequers plan or whatever is left of it and oppose leaving the EU with no deal. And it is inconceivable that we should crash out of Europe with no deal &ndash that would be a national disaster.That is why if Parliament votes down a Tory deal or the government fails to reach any deal at all we would press for a general election. Failing that, all options are on the table. Brexit is about the future of our country and our vital interests.

title: Central line tube rail strike closures london underground tfl Nick Ferrari
story: Nick Ferrari lashed out at tube union boss Finn Brennan over the latest Central Line strikes.Speaking on LBC, the radio presenter asked: &ldquoHow does inconveniencing hundreds of thousands, possibly a million people, help your case?The Aslef District Organiser for London Underground responded: &ldquoIt&rsquos incredibly frustrating to end up in this situation and time and again it&rsquos happened.&ldquoThere seems to be a deliberate strategy on London Underground management of not dealing with problems quickly.&ldquo                'Blood EVERYWHERE' - Man stabbed in FACE on London Underground                London Tube CHAOS: Central Line CLOSED and Waterloo and City Line DOWNMr Ferrari interjected: &ldquoBut you&rsquore not listening to the question Mr Brennan.&ldquoMy listeners and the people that use the service that your colleagues provide, how does it help them by stopping their tube trains?To which Mr Brennan replied: &ldquoHow it may help is if it brings people to put some pressure on London Underground management to stop these problems arising.&ldquoNow this was a 90 percent &lsquoYes&rsquo vote, virtually every driver on the Central Line is on strike today.&ldquoIt shows the level of frustration about how poorly people are treated - we can&rsquot keep continuing having these industrial relations problems on London Underground&ldquoI think people at the top of Tfl now need to take a serious grip, let&rsquos stop going from dispute to dispute.The radio host leaned back in his chair and let out a sigh before saying: &ldquoWell on that we can definitely agree.London tube strikes on the Central Line and Waterloo &amp City Line have left thousands of commuters struggling to get to work this morning.Central Line tube strike: Nick Ferrari blasted the tube union boss for not listening to his question (Image: LBC)Normal service is not set to resume on the affected lines until mid-morning on Saturday.The 800,000 passengers who use the Central Line on a daily basis are being forced to use other lines.The strike action has also caused big crowds to form outside certain stations served by the Central Line, including Ilford and Oxford Circus.One tube user tweeted: &ldquoTube strike really holds London hostage!

title: Brexit news update Peoples Vote Labour Party Chuka Umunna latest
story: Speaking exclusively to Express, the Sweden Democrats MEP argued Labour Remainers' calls to stop Brexit mislead the British electorate as they fail to take into account Britain would have to re-apply for its membership to the Brussels bloc in order to backtrack on its decision to leave.Mr Lundgren claimed that with the triggering of Article 50 Britain would have to renegotiate its membership to the European Union should it wish to reverse Britons 2016 decision.He argued an application to become members of the Brussels bloc again would probably see the UK having to join the eurozone and adopt the common currency.&nbspThe Swedish MEP added the UK would also no longer be part of the Schengen agreement and be treated as a new member of the EU.                Brexiteer MP lashes second referendum bid with CRUCIAL point                Farage outlines two things British people must to stop Brexit BETRAYALHe said: &ldquoThe Labour Party is not taking responsibility.&ldquoThey are doing mind games in people&rsquos heads trying to convince them that if you vote for Labour we will wind it back and we will remain members of the European Union.&ldquoI&rsquom sorry, it&rsquos not that easy.&ldquoYou have handed in the application of leaving the European Union.&ldquoIf you want to stay now, you would have to hand in an application of becoming a member.Brexit news: Swedesh MEP Peter Lundgren claims UK would have to join eurozone to remain in EU (Image: &bullEUROPEAN PARLIAMENT)&ldquoAnd then for sure you will not have the pound anymore, you will have the euro.&ldquoYou will not have any rebait, you will not have the Schengen agreement.&ldquoSo it&rsquos a completely different situation.&ldquoAnd I&rsquom quite surprised that the Leave side isn&rsquot taking this situation up much more as an argument.Labour MP Chuka Umunna, who&nbsphas repeatedly spoken out against the British Government's plans to break up from Brussels, claimed Brexit was still a big if on Thursday.Mr Umunna has become a vocal supporter of the People's Vote campaign calling for a second Brexit referendum.Speaking to BBC This Week about the future of the Conservative Party post-Brexit, the Labour arch-Remainer said: I think they probably will want to start afresh but the problem is they are never going to be able to run away from Brexit.If Brexit happens &ndash which is a big if, I don&rsquot accept it is inevitable &ndash your approach to Brexit will become part of your economic policy whether you like it or not.

title: Brexit news Chris Philp Baroness Kennedy second referendum EU latest people vote latest
story: The Conservative MP tore into Baroness Kennedy for suggesting British voters have changed their mind about Brexit and will want a second vote on whether to leave the European Union.Mr Philp insisted he will follow the instructions of the majority of Britons to ensure the UK breaks ties with Brussels instead of ignoring their will.Speaking on BBC Live Politics, the West Wickham MP said: I voted to hold the referendum. The British Government don&rsquot want a no deal, I don&rsquot want no deal.The only people who will force us into a no deal position is the European Union if they don&rsquot engage constructively in these talks.Baroness Kennedy suggested British voters had begun to change their mind about Brexit after learning so much about the consequences of leaving the EU.&nbspBrexit news: Chris Philp said he will not ignore the will of British people with a new vote (Image: BBC)The Labour peer also claimed a potential new ballot would ask Britons to have a say on the final terms of the agreement reached with Brussels rather than repeating the question of the 2016&nbspreferendum.She said: I do think increasingly people are saying &lsquowe have learned so much in the last two years&rsquo about what the implications of all of this are and it is going to be hugely impacting on their life that I actually do think there is every chance there will be a second vote.It will be a new vote, it will &lsquodo we like what is coming out of this?&rsquo and &lsquodo we like how all of this looks?&rsquo And people don&rsquot like what they are seeing.Theresa May has vowed there will not be a second referendum on leaving the EU, saying it would be a &ldquogross betrayal of democracy.Mrs May said: &ldquoIn the summer of 2016, millions came out to have their say. In many cases, for the first time in decades, they trusted that their vote would count that after years of feeling ignored by politics, their voices would be heard.&ldquoTo ask the question all over again would be a gross betrayal of our democracy &ndash and a betrayal of that trust.

title: David Attenborough BBC Blue Planet Newsnight
story: The veteran television presenter, 92, said there was &ldquostill a place in television for people like him.Cassian Harrison told the Edinburgh International Television Festival in August: &ldquoThere&rsquos a mode of programming that involves a presenter, usually white, middle-aged and male, standing on a hill and &lsquotelling you like it is.&rsquo&ldquoWe all recognise the era of that has passed.Evan Davis asked Sir David if he thought the BBC editor had him in mind when he made such claim. title: Fish and chip shop Terry s Chocolate Orange Christmas
story: The deep-fried Terry's Chocolate Orange is really taking off (Image: ADAM'S BAY)Eatery Adam&rsquos Bay started offering locals the battered treat ahead of Christmas.&nbspAnd so far the sickly surprise has been flying off the shelves.&nbspThe shop in Gainsborough, Lincs, asked their customers to choose one item to become their novelty deep-fried snack for the festive season.Battered mince pies, yule log and Christmas pudding were also among the options.&nbspYet when the shop workers tried the deep-fried Terry&rsquos Chocolate Orange, they knew it was a winner.&nbspOwner Helena Papadamou said: &ldquoIt was sublime so we decided to make it our novelty item for Christmas.It's definitely more of a sharer. When we tried it, we broke it into segments each and the middle just oozed out all melted.&ldquoIt was very gooey too.In the restaurant we serve it with ice cream but there also is an option with takeaway to buy it with a pot of ice cream, she told Lincolnshire Live.This isn't the first novelty item to be battered in the shop (Image: ADAM'S BAY)This isn&rsquot the first time the shop has turned to an unorthodox novelty item.&nbspThey previously sold battered Creme Eggs at Easter and battered pigs in blankets last Christmas.&nbspTheir rare items are becoming so well-known now that people are coming from all over the UK.Helena said: One morning as soon as we opened, someone had driven all the way from Lincoln and ordered four of the battered chocolate oranges.&ldquoSince we started selling them (Oct 1) we have sold 18 and it's all gone quite insane really.

title: BBC Question time Brexit news QT George the Poet xenophobia
story: The BBC Question Time debate about post-Brexit immigration plans spiralled into a furious row between two members of the audience after one of them claimed Britain was the least racist country in Europe.The row began when BBC Question Time guest George The Poet claimed the debate around post-Brexit immigration in Britain was driven by British xenophobia.A member of the audience who disagreed with with George the Poet then claimed the UK was the least racist society across Europe.To which George The Poet replied: &ldquoOh, phew! Thank you so much. So I didn&rsquot get stopped by police outside of my mum&rsquos house earlier this year.                QT audience member praises Rees-Mogg for his Brexit approach&ldquoThat didn&rsquot happen to me. Thank you. I should have just explained that to the police officers who stopped me.The young man in the audience hit back at the comments, which led to a woman in the audience to claim the other audience member did not agree with the artist's point of view simply because - being a white man - he was not experiencing racism in his own country.She said: &ldquoIt&rsquos funny that you&rsquore a white man saying that. It&rsquos actually hilarious.&ldquoYou&rsquore a white man saying that there is no racism in this country.BBC Question Time: Huge row erupts between audience members (Image: BBC)Mr Philp told BBC&rsquos Politics Live the comments from the woman made him &ldquouncomfortable. He said: &ldquoI think the idea that only certain people can comment uncertain issues based on their identity is a bit of a dangerous one.&ldquoIt&rsquos like saying only people who work in finance can comment on finance. I understand people have different experiences to bring to the table, obviously.&ldquoBut I am very uncomfortable that certain people are told because of their identity, the colour of their skin, they can&rsquot comment on certain topics. That is wrong. But I think, generally, this country has come a huge way.&ldquoIf you look at what happened in Germany just a few weeks ago with immigrants being attacked simply for being immigrants. We haven&rsquot seen anything like that in this country for a very long time.&ldquoYou&rsquore not the one walking down the street being screened at. That&rsquos not happening to you.&ldquoYou&rsquore not a young black man walking across the street being stopped by the police.&ldquoDon&rsquot tell me to calm down. I don&rsquot need to calm down. You&rsquore not experiencing this and that&rsquos why you don&rsquot agree with it.The debate follows a pledge by Prime Minister Theresa May to bring free movement to an end &ldquoonce and for all with her new immigration policy.The Prime Minister announced that her future immigration policy would deliver on the result of the Brexit referendum.She also mentioned that the new system would prioritise high-skilled workers.Speaking live on BBC, the Prime Minister declared: &ldquoOur future immigration policy delivers on the result of the referendum, takes back control of our borders and ensures free movement comes to an end once and for all.&ldquoWe will be deciding who comes into this country, but we recognise businesses say that there are skills they need to bring into this country, so the new system is not going to be based on where people come from, but what they can contribute to our economy - the skills that they have.&ldquoNow of course we are also working as a Government to ensure that we&rsquore building up the skills of young people here in the UK, but our new immigration policy is crucially going to ensure that free movement ends.&ldquoIt will be determined by their contribution to our economy, not where they come from.

story: Conspiracy theorists have been flogging the idea that NASA is covering up an alien race on Mars for some time.However, there has never been any substantial evidence to back these claims.But one alien enthusiast believes he now has the answer and is hoping to expose NASA.YouTube channel &lsquoMars Anomalies and Beyond&rsquo, narrated by a man who gives his name as just Chris, uploaded a video which apparently shows proof of life on the Red Planet.                UFO sighting: Alien spaceship spotted passing THROUGH the SUNThe first notable thing that Chris points out is seemingly a vehicle in the distant foreground, bit a backdrop of dusty red.But as Chris points out: &ldquoYou never see anything in the background of these photos from NASA.He believes NASA is editing the images to block out background cities.By using &ldquophoto enhancing software, Christ believes he spotted the outline of a city including large buildings on the horizon.Alien hunters find &lsquoCITY on Mars&rsquo: Shock claim Nasa pictures show CARS and buildings (Image: )The supposed vehicles on Mars (Image: YOUTUBE)He said: &ldquoThe question is, what did his photo enhancing software uncover?&ldquoDid it find something that NASA was hiding in the background of the photo as they always do in the Martian photos?&ldquoIs this a city in the background or simple photo artefacts? In my opinion, I believe we are seeing a city.&ldquoThere is no way to clarify this so it is pure speculation but I think it is wild that if these are in fact vehicles, it wouldn&rsquot surprise me if these were some kind of structures behind it.An enhanced image seems to show a city in the background (Image: YOUTUBE)Some were in agreement with Chris&rsquos theory.One person said: &ldquoit&rsquos either buildings on Mars or it&rsquos Earth made too look like Mars. title: russia news vladimir putin popularity polls
story: Mr Putin&rsquos approval ratings slumped when just 58 percent of Russians said they could trust him, a figure down 75 percent after the unpopular law was written in.Survey results by the independent Levada Centre revealed he had similar ratings at the time of the annexation of Crimea in 2014 when at around that time 51 percent of Russian voters had faith in him.After military intervention in Crimea saw the region&rsquos annexation, his approval ratings skyrocketed to 82 percent.Unease came as a pension reform that saw the pension age increase from 60 to 65 for men and woman sparked protests by both Mr Putin&rsquos liberal opposition and the communist voters that support him.                World War 3: Russia declare WAR and Putin is WINNING &ndash 'UK must FIGHT'                Vladimir Putin's Russia is now an enemy of the West As a result of unrest, he relaxed the law slightly for women, who are now expected to work until the age of 63 instead of 65 in a bid to win back voters.The poll results also revealed Russians have more faith in their army than their president, after the military, which has had a huge modernisation drive after repeated tensions with China, scored a 66 percent approval rating.Levada Centre sociologist Denis Volkov told Kommersant newspaper: &ldquoThe pre-election mood revived and pushed up Vladimir Putin's rating.&ldquoAfter the election, however, the mobilisation of his supporters ended, and instead of the promised increase in wages, people got Chemical Weapons (OPCW) in The Hague, having received assistance from the help of UK intelligence.Peter Wilson, UK ambassador in The Hague, said both the Foreign Office and Defence and Science Technology Laboratory at Porton Down were also targeted by a group of GRU military intelligence service hackers in Russia known as Sandworm.Dutch authorities added GRU operatives sent &ldquospear phishing emails to the headquarters of the OPCW in an attempt to compromise its computers.The news comes after Russia was yesterday accused of behaving like a &ldquopariah state (Image: )When that failed, a GRU close access team was sent from Russia to the Netherlands to try to penetrate their cyber defences from close quarters.This resulted in Dutch security services seizing a hired car containing sophisticated hacking equipment the GRU men were using near the OPCW building on April 13.Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson said: &ldquoThese are the actions of a pariah state and we will continue working with allies to isolate them and make them understand they cannot conduct themselves in such a way.Russia has continued to deny any involvement in the attack and say both men were tourists who visited Salisbury Cathedral.

title: michael schumacher news health latest ross brawn ferrari F1
story: Ross Brawn said Michael Schumacher's win at Suzuka in 2000 was a highlight of his career (Image:  IMAGES)Ross Brawn celebrated all seven title wins with Schumacher as chief technical officer for Benetton and then Ferrari.He now serves as F1&rsquos managing director, but said his personal highlight after a decade of working with the German superstar was his performance in southern Japan.Speaking to motorsport website Speedweek, Brawn said: I associate so many memories with this track, and these are mainly related to a driver who dominated Suzuka and that was Michael Schumacher.&ldquoThe best and most emotional experience was the win of 2000, with which he gave Ferrari the first title after a dry spell of 21 years.                Lewis Hamilton responds to Michael Schumacher Ferrari questionI can still remember the feeling of joy when Michael returned to the track after his second pit stop before his title rival Mika Hakkinen and also the intense 13 race laps that followed to the finish.&ldquoThe incredible relief and the overwhelming joy as the checkered flag dropped stands out. This experience will not be forgotten.The Japanese Grand Prix at Suzuka has traditionally been one of the final races of the F1 calendar, meaning drivers are often still battling it out for much-needed points to finish the season in first place.Brawn added: &ldquoHow could you forget the epic duels of Alain Prost and Ayrton Senna?Brawn served as technical director at Benetton and Ferrari for Schumacher&rsquos world championship wins (Image:  IMAGES)                Michael Schumacher&rsquos son Mick MUST follow father to drive in F1                F1 news: Ferrari discuss Michael Schumacher&rsquos son linking up with team&ldquoFor me personally, of course, other races are in the foreground, such as the 2003 GP, which Rubens Barrichello won, while Michael was catching up from behind and fought his way to eighth place - with which he earned enough points to win his sixth World Cup title.Michael Schumacher joined Ferrari from Benetton in 1996 after The Prancing Horse had gone for more than two decades without a win in the Drivers&rsquo Championship. Brawn joined him less than a year later.F1 legend Schumacher was placed in a medically induced coma after suffering a severe head injury while skiing in 2013.Updates on the 49-year-old&rsquos condition have been few and far between as his family seeks to maintain his privacy.F1 legend Schumacher won seven championships between 1994 and 2004 (Image:  IMAGES)The Japanese Grand Prix at Suzuka is typically one of the final races of the season (Image:  IMAGES)However a family statement released in 2015 said that Schumacher was showing &ldquomoments of consciousness and awakening.His manager Sabine Kehm has refused to provide any further details on his health, saying: Michael's health is not a public issue, and so we will continue to make no comment in that regard.We have to protect his intimate sphere. Legally seen and in the longer term, every statement related to his health would diminish the extent of his intimate sphere.Additional reporting by Monika Pallenberg.

story: But do you know how Halloween got its name and why we celebrate it  Heres the lowdown...Halloween falls every year on October , which is a Wednesday this year.It is held the day before All Saints’ Day, which is a Christian festival used to celebrate recognised saints.Halloween activities typically involve trick or treating and dressing up in fancy dress.The word Halloween comes from Hallowe’en, meaning “hallowed evening” or holy evening.It is widely thought that Halloween traditions came from Celtic harvest festivals of Samhain, although some people support the view that Halloween began independently as a Christian festival.Samhain was a celebration of the end of the harvest season, and means summer’s end.People at this time thought the walls between worlds were thin and spirits could pass through into our realm, and it was feared they may damage crops for the next season.To appease any spirits, gaels would set up places at their dinner tables for the spirits and light bonfires to scare off evil spirits.There are a number of ways to celebrate the festival, whether you want to go out or enjoy it from the comfort of your home.These include:Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc press doesnt get tabloids right
story: Theories have ranged from Keeley Hawes’ acting to Richard Madden’s arse, without considering a more obvious possibility.Every other competing drama was either too dull , too grim , or just too rubbish.Which brings me to Press, a series I’d wanted to avoid on the obvious grounds there was never any possibility I was going to like a BBC drama about tabloids.But what the hell. It was a quiet week, so I watched the first four episodes and, to my surprise and delight, I hated Press even more than I expected.The set-up’s the deal-breaker, of course. We’ve got a right-wing red-top called The Post, that’s very obviously meant to be The Sun, and a left-wing broadsheet The Herald, which is equally obviously , house Bible of the BBC.The former is edited by soul-selling clone Duncan Allen, played by the brilliant Ben Chaplin, who does actually resemble a couple of ex-colleagues.By rights then, the female lead should be The Herald’s editor, Amina Chaudury, played by Priyanga Burford.But she can’t act, so the responsibility’s fallen to Charlotte Riley as northern, working-class brick of Deputy News Editor Holly Evans, who fits the social profile of your averagewoman about as comfortably as Roy Chubby Brown fits a mankini.Next weird thing you probably notice about Press is that nearly all the characters are giving speeches, rather than talking normally to each other.Especially the insufferable broadsheet hacks, who never stop reminding each other “we speak the truth to the powerful”, and that “people buy The Herald for the truth”.Why do people buy The Post Sun It’s never really occurred to writer Mike “Doctor Foster” Bartlett, who clearly didn’t read our newspaper before he sat down to type Press, at his desk on the summit of Mount Olympus, and has probably never met a tabloid reader either, without telling them: “Keep the change.”How can I be so sure Because it’s got almost every single professional and technical aspect wrong, from Duncan’s insistence he’s going to do a spread “On page five and six” , to the week one headline The Post produced about the gay, blackmailed footballer who committed suicide: “Parents never knew their son.”Which is the sort of meaningless, esoteric b******s that would get thrown back at a student newspaper sub.That’s another unconvincing thing about Press, incidentally. No one swears. And I wouldn’t mind so muchthere were some decent stories to see us through, but there aren’t.There’s a Katie Hopkins figure floating around, a few cut-and-pasted bits of very old tabloid legendand some deep state conspiracy cobblers, which the BBC’s probably got written into Raa Raa The Noisy Lion these days.Duncan also has the vague hots for Holly, until such time as Ed off the newsdesk tells him she likes having it off in a grey vest.That’s about your lot, though.As always happens when British TV tries to dramatise the Press, the writer’s left-of-centre political agenda and prejudices trump everything .This is why Americans do it so much better, andyou want to see how newspapers really operate you’ll get a much better idea from Billy Wilder’s  film The Front Page than you ever will from Press.I’ll say this for the BBC production team though, they might not have much of an ear for newspaper dialogue, but they’ve got a hell of an eye for interior design and have duplicated one item of our office kitchen crockery perfectly.Mugs.“I don’t bend in the middle any more, to be honest.”Then just slap him around a bit.Improvise, woman.FURTHER proof,it were needed, there’s not a single television format that can’t be improved by the presence of one or two of the Happy Mondays arrived on Friday.A special BBC Music Day edition of Bargain Hunt, featuring Bez and Rowetta versus Pulp’s Jarvis Cocker and Candida Doyle, which will go down in daytime TV folklore.Attempting to keep them in some sort of order, at the Kent showground’s antique fair, was BH regular Charlie Ross, who didn’t get very far with his preliminary question: “How did it all start with the Happy Mondays, Bez ”“You really don’t want to know.”So you really couldn’t blame him for looking a bit nervous when he sent the pair of them away with £ in used notes.Half an hour later, though, Bez and Rowetta were back, with three items, including a biscuit tin and a to-die-for rustic, bygone horse collar mirror that’s yours for just  quid.It made them a respectable £ profit at auction, as well, and flattened Pulp’s efforts in the process.At which point things got a bit dark.Charlie noted “an irregularity”, the Mondays were hauled back on set, like guilty schoolkids, and the host was forced to explain that the winsome and very obliging woman at the back of the auction hall, who kept bidding for his items was in fact: “Bez’s girlfriend.”Not angry, Bez, just disappointed.IF you’ve never seen the brilliant Simpsons episode where Homer gives Pinchy, his pet lobster, a really hot bath, Google it as soon as you can.Then immediately after, watch Channel ’s darkly funny latest episode of Celebrity Island With Bear Grylls, where a pig wandered into camp, on Sunday night.Even more obligingly it then started fattening itself up on the celebs’ leftovers and inviting the obvious by crapping its load everywhere.While some sensed dinner, Towie’s Pete Wicks had a better idea.He named the pig Colin, took it for a walk and then tethered it with a rope to some rocks.Whereupon Colin, with the sort of demonic squeals and grunts you last heard on Deliverance, promptly strangled himself to death.Presented with this tragedy, you or I or Martin Kemp from Spandau Ballet, might’ve drawn the obvious conclusion and, like Homer Simpson, tucked in Not this lot.Instead Colin was buried at sea, with full military honours, to avoid “hurting Pete’s feelings”, floating off into the sunset like a warning to humanity.This MorningSemra Haksever: “I call myself an eclectic witch, so I take dferent little bits of magic from all over the place.So it’s all b******sOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: budget must put money in pockets
story: For all the wise words in his conference speech — on the opportunities of new technology, the horric dangers of Corbyn’s socialism and the importance of job-creating businesses — he needs answers to more immediate questions.The signs are ominous. The Chancellor, while admitting “st Century capitalism must deliver” for ordinary people, apparently intends to take MORE of our money for the NHS in his upcoming Budget.Polls apparently show voters are OK with that. But wait till it comes out of wage packets. Skint workers won’t thank the Tories for bailing out the health ­service. They’ll desert them for grabbing yet more of their take-home pay.Mr Hammond’s speech wasn’t all bad. His case against socialism was well put. Likewise his view that no sane party should try to outbid Corbyn’s ruinous spending pledges. We welcome his proposed digital services tax on Google and Facebookit can be made to work. ut Tory fortunes hinge on Brexit — and pay rises easily outstripping inflation.The Budget MUST put more money in pockets . . . not remove it with a tax raid or a suicidal rise in fuel duty.THE EU’s cry-bullies are OUTRAGED that Jeremy Hunt compared their aggression to the old Soviet Union. Well, diddums.He noted, quite reasonably, that Brussels’ forcible attempts to lock Britain in and deter others from leaving was ­reminiscent of the Soviet empire’s treatment of its member states.It is a figure of speech. The Foreign Secretary’s not literally comparing Juncker to Stalin’s regime of mass murder. And the EU has no defence. Which is why its lackeys, such as curtain-haired clown Guy Verhofstadt, instead wilfully misinterpreted him for dramatic effect.One even whined it could “damage relations” with other member states. Are they for real  The French president brands Brexit campaigners “liars” — implying .million Brits are dupes. Donald Tusk humiliates our PM. But WE’RE in danger of souring relations.Give it a rest, EU fools.HOW appalling that the sisters of terror victim cop Keith Palmer have no Legal Aid to pursue the truth at his inquest.Michelle Palmer and Angela Clark want to hire an independent expert to assess whether a permanent armed presence at Parliament’s Carriage Gates entrance might have saved their brother.But the Legal Aid Agency hasn’t processed their application. title: more young people are feeling lonely
story: The Eleanor Rigby of Beatles legend: “All the lonely people, where do they all come from ”An answer emerged this week — and they come from a surprising place.The loneliest people are healthy, thriving young adults, kicking off their career and probably renting a room in a city.According to new university research for the BBC, levels of loneliness are highest among  to -year-olds, with  per cent saying they often, or very often, feel it. In contrast, the over-s are positively chipper: Only  per cent of this group reported feelings of isolation.Now, I’m  and, depressingly, these statistics don’t surprise me.At first glance, it looks like young people have it easy when it comes to making friends.At  or thereabouts, more than  per cent of them will be packed off to university where they’ll move in with a group of like-minded people of the same age and be encouraged to drink and party like there’s no tomorrow.Which, when you’re only required to stumble out of bed for one pm lecture, there essentially isn’t.Rather than relying on friends of tenuous friends for dubious introductions, young people these days can simply download an app and get the details of thousands of eligible strangers delivered straight to their mobile phones.Add into the mix social media ­— which allows its users to connect with everyone they’ve ever met instantaneously at any given moment — and it’s hard to imagine how any young people could possibly be lonely, let alone  per cent.But there are two sides to every coin.University — though a godsend when it comes to meeting new people — can be a problem when it comes to staying in touch with them. Saddled with bottomless debt, young graduates simply don’t have the cash to socialise.When a round for six at a London pub will set you back  quid, is it any wonder that more and more young people are opting to stay at home Dating apps, too, come with their pitfalls. Yes, it’s nice to have a database of singletons in your pocket, but the ubiquity of Tinder and Bumble mean it’s now considered almost socially awkward to speak to someone you fancy in person.A friend of mine, who has absolutely no problem propositioning women on Tinder, hasn’t yet found the courage to ask for his next-door neighbour’s number, four months after she moved in.As for social media, young people like me are increasingly discovering that “staying connected” is a mixed blessing at best. With no excuse to lose touch, my generation holds on to friends we’ve outgrown, leaving us with no time to make new ones. It may sound callous, but there’s an art to shedding friends, and thanks to our social media addiction, we seem to have lost it.What’s more, earnest  to -year-olds seem to be taking to heart the faddish health advice that adults have been merrily ignoring for years, making it even harder for them to socialise because they fear alcohol, and even food.At the end of a recent party I got chatting to a fun young woman, so I suggested some pub grub at a boozer to round off the evening. How wrong I was.She explained in detail she was vegan and on a gluten-free diet , so the pub menu would not cater for her needs.I decided not to pursue it.So I say it’s time snowflake millennials took a bit of responsibility for their own feelings of isolation.Last month commentators wagged their fingers at the big tech companies after a survey by charity YoungMinds revealed a greater number of young people view social media as having a negative impact on the way they feel about themselves than those who report a positive impact.But it was never suggested depressed young people should simply put away their phones and do something .Mollycoddled millennials believe having a thriving social circle is a human right, rather than an ongoing project.Instead of popping to the pub for a pick-me-up with whoever happens to be around, a lonely young person will all too often turn to the internet for a spot of indulgent self-reflection, or to the gym for Insta-friendly self-improvement.As a result, pubs are closing at a rate of  a day, and sites such as Tumblr are overflowing with posters instructing users to “forget the haters” and “shine like the star that you are”.Of course, social media is made to be addictive. But surely putting down a phone can’t be an insurmountable challenge for an educated generation of young people  Dwelling on yourself is the surest route to a lonely lestyle, so instead of posting doleful, introspective memes on social media or clinging to tired old friendships, lonely young people should find the guts to get outside and look outwards.Making and keeping real friends takes work, and it’s time young people started putting the hours in.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: life on street where hookers beg school run dads for 30 alleyway romps and say rush hours our best time
story: Young women - wearing mini dresses and stilettos - openly tout for business in front of primary schoolkids as dawn breaks over Hassle Road in Hull, East Yorkshire.Loitering near bus stops and outside shops, they offer passers-by cheaper rates for sex outdoors.One told The Sun Online am is the peak time because: “Its rush hour, babe.”Locals warn the grim situation is now intolerable, with the number of women patrolling the street rocketing.On Friday morning, one sex worker approached our reporter as kids walked to one of the seven nearby primary schools today.Dressed in tight jeans and a black leather jacket, the dark haired girl in her late s, begged: Do you want business ”Asked why she was out in broad daylight, she replied: “It’s rush hour babe. It’s the best time.When everyone is going to work. Have you got a car  It’s £ for sex or £ for a [sex act].Another sex worker, aged around , offered our reporter full outdoor sex for £.She said: “Do you want business  Do you want it indoors or outdoors  It’s £ for sexyou want to go back to my flat.“If you want it outdoors it’s £ for oral sex or £ for sex. Theres an alley just around the corner.I will be here for a bit babe - butI get another job I will be gone.“There’s a cash point just across the road or at the garage. Where are you parked  It’s best in a car.She then whispered that she offered punters the chance to touch her all over for twenty quid.One mum shook her head in despair as she walked her little boy to school.She said: “I work in one of the shops and they are often there when I go to work at eight in the morning after I take my boy to school. It’s terrible.”Meanwhile, other horried locals said they are regularly approached as early as am as they make their way to work.Funeral director Steve Smith, , claims he was solicited while standing at a cash machine before starting work.He told The Sun Online: “I was stood outside the bank and she said: ‘Are you looking for business “I thought that was funny since I am in the funeral business. She was a bit young to end up in a box.“I was wearing my suit and funeral gear and she was dressed in a pair of shorts and a crop top so it was a really bizarre thing to happen at am.Just four years ago, Hull became the first UK city to create a prostitute-free zone, meaning people caught loitering, soliciting or having sex in the area could be arrested and charged.However, the ban has done little to deter the problem, and residents now claim as many as  to  prostitutes tout the streets every day.Newsagent Jo Thirkettle, , said: “They wear skirts like belts, hot pants and other revealing stuff.“They come into the shop asking the customers ‘Do you want business ’ When I tell them to go outside they go after blokes using the cash machine.“They don’t charge very much because people around here can’t afford much anyway.Many of the girls take their customers to an open car park behind the shops which is littered with condoms, cigarette butts, empty beer cans and smashed spirits bottles.Some are even said to be using a disused phone box for sex, often leaving their business cards behind along with condoms, syringes and other drugs paraphernalia.There are seven primary schools within a mile radius of the road - Adelaide, Newington Academy, Hessle Penhurst, Francis Askew, Wheeler, Chiltern and St Georges Primary - as well as two nurseries.A local shop owner, who did not wish to be named, said: There have been prostitutes down here for decades.“They seem to come go – sometimes they are at one end of the street and sometimes at the other.Then they will disappear altogether for a few weeks trying a dferent area. But they always come back.“You’ll see them arguing among themselves about pitches and where they should stand.“I’ve seen them here when I start opening up at am.”Last year, the police launched a clampdown on the notorious spot.Coppers caught  kerb crawlers approaching prostitutes over a three-month period,  of them were then slapped with section  orders, banning them from the area.Councillor Daren Hale insists everything is being done to clampdown on the number of sex workers which “causes misery for residents.”Inspector Kirsty Tock, of the Hull central community policing team, said: “Hessle Road remains our main focus and, at the moment, we are tackling those seeking out sex workers.“We are continuing to carry out patrols and using the injunctions to prevent prostitution on Hull’s streets.“We have changed our approach recently and are using plain-clothes officers and now punters are feeling the full force of these section  orders.We are also using CCTV to collect further evidence.

title: conservative party brexit unity rod liddle opinion
story: I don’t think Theresa May is going to be on Strictly any time soon. Whoever convinced her it would be dead cool to walk on stage at the party conference and jig about to an Abba song needs a bit of invasive brain surgery, right now.It was like a remake of Re-Animator, or Night Of The Living Dead.There’s no point in Theresa trying to tell us she’s the le and soul of the party and actually a bloody good laugh.We know she isn’t. She’s about as charismatic as an underdone crumpet on a wet Sunday. But she doesn’t need to be Ginger Rogers. She’s the Prime Minister.And you have to give her credit for doggedly sticking to that role. EvenI’m not convinced she’s been doing it terribly well.But on Brexit — God, how mind-numbingly boring the whole thing is — she has a good point.I’m not a fan of her Chequers deal for us to leave the European Union. I think we’re giving too much away. I’d rather have a no-deal exit.But time is pressing. And I’m aware that while we Leavers won the referendum, the margin was comparatively small. So we ought to be gracious and accept a little bit of a compromise. Try to strike a respectable deal with those gangsters from insignicant countries.And a little further down the line, tweak the arrangements a little to suit us better. In the meantime, just strike the deal.And that means getting behind May and presenting a united front to Europe. Most of the Conservative MPs understand that, even the arch-Brexiteers like the excellent Michael Gove.But Bfo the Blundering Bear does not. I’m talking about Boris Johnson. Now he IS fun and good company. But he’s about as likely to become Prime Minister as I am to cop off with Emily Ratajkowski after a few pints and a quick meal at the Chicken Cottage.He has very little support among his political colleagues. He has a lot more among Conservative activists. But very little among voters north of Watford.And yet Bfo was at it again this week. Taking the p**s out of the Prime Minister. And making a rousing speech to his hardcore supporters. Demanding we tell the EU to stuff it.Well, there was a time when we should have told the EU to stuff it — two years ago when we first started negotiations.That time has passed. A lack of confidence from the Government and a ided party let us down.Now is the time to show a bit of unity and wring a deal out of the deathly bureaucrats. Maybe not the Chequers deal — May didn’t mention the word at all during her speech — but a version of it.Otherwise we’ll have a General Election on our hands. One the Tories will lose. And you’ll wake up to find John McDonnell is in charge of your finances and Diane Abbott is Home Secretary.Come on — surely that should concentrate the mind a little Hero of the week is Jane Lunnon, head of a girls’ school in South London.She has stuck the boot into “image-obsessed” reality TV – especially that coven of gurning and pouting imbeciles in Love Island, such as Megan Barton Hanson.Such programmes are “incredibly damaging” to young people, she reckons, calling them “trivial nonsense”.I think Jane is right. And the same goes for all those hyped-up talent shows where people with no talent – just a lust for fame – get judged on their appalling performances by people with no talent.Kids need to know the dference between fame for fame’s sake – and real achievement.Its horrible that Corine Remande has lost the sight in one eye after she was hit by a golf ball during the Ryder Cup.The poor woman was standing among spectators when Brooks Koepka’s tee shot hit her in the face.She’s now threatening legal action against the organisers. She says they didn’t give spectators enough protection.This is ludicrous. What were they supposed to do And what will happen is that in future crowds will be kept even further back from the action. Just because of one horrible accident.Wait until the same thing happens in cricket...The uni magazine said: “It was argued that the loud noise of traditional clapping and whooping pose an issue to students with anxiety or sensory issues. BSL clapping – or, jazz hands – would be a more inclusive form of expression.”With anxiety or sensory issues  What is wrong with these people They are “triggered” by almost everything. Especially by people who have views which dfer from their own.That REALLY triggers them. They shouldn’t be at university. They should be safe at home with mummy and daddy.That old windbag Mahathir Mohamad has been visiting the UK.Lovely to have him, of course. He’s the boss of Muslim-dominated Malaysia and he hates Jews.He was at it again over here. Said they all had “hook noses”.And that they were the cause of all the trouble in the Middle East.He’s allowed his view, of course, evenit is one based on hatred and the ideology of his own interpretation of his religion.But how would it beI said Muslims are the cause of most of the trouble in the world I’d be up before the Old Bill for a hate crime before you could say Islamic State.This is because Asian countries are getting more and more wealthy.I suppose this is a good thing. Problem is, I can’t stand them, the middle class.And the thought of nearly four billion people eating avocado on toast while doing Pilates then listening to Coldplay in their Volvo XCs makes me feel terribly queasy.The human race is being taken over by the legions of the smug. Get me outta here.Visitors to the Telford Exotic Zoo were disappointed by the penguins. They just stood, stock still.This is because they are plastic model penguins. The zoo had been unable to get the real thing.And here’s a tip for the zoo owners. Don’t buy any real penguins, stick to the models.I think plastic penguins would be far better suited to an enclosure of a dozen square yards of shingle with a tiny drainage ditch to bathe in.Why are we allowing zoos like this to open  If I were a real penguin in Telford Exotic Zoo I’d sue them. Or beat them about the head with a flipper.Have you seen Vladimir Putin’s new calendar There he is, standing naked in water, muscles rippling, looking stern.Another one has him cuddling a baby leopard.I hate to say this but isn’t it all a bit... um... camp And now for saying this I’ll probably end up resembling one of the glow sticks the kids buy at funfairs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rooting against cashless britain
story: But in just ten years’ time, kids will find the idea of a porcelain container for metal coins ridiculous — and will be doing their saving on a phone app with cute graphics.Face it, cash is dying out. It is dirty and unhygienic — a report out this week said it is a breeding ground for bugs.There is even a version of Monopoly with debit cards instead of notes. And last month we told you of the  century The Boot pub in Freston, Suffolk, the first boozer in the country to go cashless.This looming death has been around for a while. In August, the Bank of England said it was considering phasing out p and p coins. And ATMs are closing at a rate of  a month.Just  per cent of payments are cash, down from  per cent in . And those payments only account for three per cent in terms of the value of how much is spent.Paying on card has been on the rise ever since Barclaycard launched in , but cards too face being eclipsed by payments on mobile phones. Either way, both mean we need cash less. And that is not a bad thing, right Getting rid of cash would hit criminals and tax evaders hard as they do business in cash to make it harder for authorities to track the movement of money.Businesses would rejoice because they would not have to pay security guards to transport money and would not have to spend ages counting and bagging it.Some also reckon it is easier to keep a tab on finances when spending on cards or apps. You might forget buying that extra round at closing time in the pub, but your phone will always remember. And of course, you get consumer protection when using a credit card, along with reward points or cashback offers.Credit card firms make their money not just from interest payments but from taking a small fee for each transaction — so they offer us incentives to choose their cards. Use an Air Miles card and before long you could have a free flight to Paris or New York.More than a quarter of clothes in the UK are bought online — and you can’t use cash over the internet. As we move even more to buying online and via smartphone apps, cash will be needed less and less. Whether cash dies out in five years or  or  just depends on technology.But many are in no rush to see the back of it — and not just because of nostalgia for their old piggy banks. One consideration is: Can we entirely trust the banks to look after our money  Fraud is soaring as criminals take advantage of security issues around online banking. Banks blame customers but critics say banks need to take responsibility.We have featured victim after victim on The Sun Money columns, and they all say bank staff have turned their backs on them. There are millions of others who need cash simply because they rely on it to pay for things day to day. And it is the less well off or elderly who rely on it the most.Consumer magazine Which  — which has been campaigning against the loss of banks and ATMs — has produced research showing poorer families and older folk are hardest hit.Gareth Shaw of Which  said: “ATM and branch closures are threatening to leave behind the millions who still rely on cash. Our research highlights lower-income families and older generations will be among the worst hit.”In June, services from Visa, one of the three main card providers along with Mastercard and American Express, went down with technical issues — highlighting the risk of being solely reliable on cards and phones. “When the trolley came around on the train and the card payment wasn’t working, the only people who could eat were those with cash,” one banker explained.And what about hospitality workers  The Government has said all tips, evenon cards, must go to staff — but we all know some unscrupulous bosses will not do that. Like many, I prefer to give my tips in cash so I know the waiter or waitress gets it all.Charity collectors often have card machines now but collections for most churches, schools and small local good causes still rely on tins and the rattle of coins.Cash may well be dying out, but I still make sure I always keep some coins in my pocket just in case. And I have older relatives who still feel most comfortable with coins and notes.So until we have a population where everyone feels happy when using a card or phone, I will be rooting against a completely cashless Britain.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: thomas cook holiday customers egypt food raw meat
story: Nikk Malee, , watched the servers pick the raw meat off trays to cook it before placing it back on the same trays ready to serve to guests in the seaside resort of Hurghada.Nikk, from Scarborough, was so horried that she cut her two-week holiday short and ate only rice and bread until she could leave to avoid any potential food poisoning.And the holidaymaker, who is confined to a wheelchair due to osteoarthritis, said she was frustrated her concerns were initially brushed off by Thomas Cook – despite the series of food hygiene concerns raised from the holiday destination in recent months.Two Brits John Cooper, , and his we Susan, , died suddenly at an Egypt hotel barely half an hour down the road.Speaking to the Sun Online, Nikk said: “People need to be made aware that their lives are being put at risk by companies that have no interest in their welfare.”Thomas Cook today confirmed the chef involved has been suspended and an investigation had been launched.Nikk had been staying at Tropitel Sahl Hasheesh in Hurghada in August with her husband and carer Malcolm when she said she spotted the mishandling of the food as they prepared for a barbecue.She said: “They were bringing the meat off the small trays and started cooking it on the grill.“Then they took the same small trays, put a liner in and put the cooked meat – chicken and koftas - back on to the trays.“All the time cooking, they didn’t wash their hands and only wiped them on a piece of paper.”Nikk filmed the chefs, with the cooks seen flipping the meat on an open fire before going back to handle the raw meat.After the incident, she said: “I couldn’t feel comfortable eating there.“I ate bread alone.”The horried woman said her trip to Egypt had been ruined – demanding to be taken home a week early and moved to a dferent hotel in the meantime.She said she demanded for the barbecue to be cancelled that night, but was told it would be impossible.Instead, a meeting was organised with the hotel manager for the next morning.She said: “I told him ‘You’re going to make guests ill’.“He said he would talk them through hygiene again but I said it wasn’t good enough – that’s where you get these deaths from.”Frustrated Nikk also claimed staff had told her to delete the video, with it taking weeks for Thomas Cook to pay attention to her complaints.Since news of the sudden deaths of John and Susan Cooper, scores of tourists have described being served raw chicken and suffering food poisoning at the Steigenberger Aqua Magic in Hurghada, Egypt, this summer.A Thomas Cook spokesperson said: “We want all of our customers to enjoy their holidays with us and we are very sorry that Mr and Mrs Mallee did not enjoy their stay.“After receiving the complaint we gave them a hotel upgrade and arranged early flights home at no extra cost.“Following our investigation the hotel has suspended the chef and is putting measures in place to ensure that this doesn’t happen again.”

title: vladimir putin speech language slang gangster
story: On Wednesday, the Russian strongman President, who is renowned for using swear words, called poisoned former KGB spy Sergei Skripal a “scumbag” and a “traitor”.Putin also once advised a journalist to have his penis cut off while previously vowing to kill Chechen terrorists “in the sh*t house.”Speaking with The Sun Online, James Rogers, an expert in European geopolitics and Baltic security, claims Putin uses this language to project a “gangster” image.He said: “When he responds often in Russian he has this kind of street garble - the kind of language of the street.“Its almost like a kind of cavalier attitude“He often swears and uses cursing words - so its a kind of projection of a persona.The academic also highlights pictures of Vlad posing topless holding big guns as another example of the leader trying to cultivate a tough guy image.He added: “It’s like a gangster regime. Putin constructs himself as a strongman - think of all the bare chested photos.“It’s all part of the same projection. It’s designed to be cavalier, uncaring and robust.Rogers, a founding member of think tank the Henry Jackson Society, also branded the former KGB thug’s government “ugly and deranged”.He added: “His regime is so wild and unruly.“Putin’s government doesnt seem particularly bothered about what it does whether its the invasion of other countries or the lies and the misinformation that it spreads through out the world.”Michele Berdy, a Moscow language expert, told CNN that Putin’s speaks excellent Russian in a country where speaking properly is highly valued - meaning his use of curse words is “strategic.”She said: “Thats why Ive always thought that his slipping into this is very strategic.He decides when he wants to leave standard literary Russian and get into non-standard Russian.The Russian leader also uses threatening body language when meeting rivals.In July , Putin drew the social equivalent of a weapon when he pointed his finger at a “dominant Donald Trump at the G summit.Body language expert Judi James analysed the historic first handshake between the US President and the Moscow hard man.She said: “Hesuffered an underarm-patting from Trump that made him look like the dominant leader, so much so that Putin responded with a pointed finger, which is the body language equivalent of drawing a weapon.”In September , a then-Prime Minister Putin responded to a series of terrorists bombings in Russia by Chechen rebels.He said: “Were going to pursue the terrorists everywhere.That means, youll excuse me, well catch them in the toilet, well wipe them out in the sh*t house, finally.In , former KGB spy Vlad issued a disturbing threat to a French journalist who asked a hostile question at a summit in Brussels.Putin said: “Come to Moscow. We can offer you a circumcision.“I will recommend a doctor to carry out the operation in such a way nothing  will ever grow there again.When asked about Turkey shooting down a Russian warplane in  near the Syrian border, Putin suggested Ankara wanted to “lick the US in a certain place.”He said: “If anyone in the Turkish leadership decided to lick the Americans in a certain place - I dont knowthey acted correctly or not -- I dont know whether the Americans need that.According to reports, the Kremlin strongman was using a Russian expression which means to lick someone’s bum.In , when asked about his supposed wealth, he said: “Thats such garbage. They picked it out of their noses and smeared it on their papers.”When asked about his sex le in , Vlad said: Theyve asked me when I began having sex.I dont remember - I remember exactly when I did it the last time. I can define that right down to the minute.

title: emmanuel macron stop brexit second eu referendum
story: The Prime Minister warned the rest of her ministers that the French hardline boss is holding out hope that another referendum could be on the cards.And it might push EU leaders into giving us a bad dealthey think they can force another vote where Britain opts to stay in the bloc, The Times reported.The French President is pushing for the EU to pursue a hardline approach with Mrs May in Brexit talks - and is said to be among several members who want to punish us for leaving.He told other leaders that Britains current Chequers deal wouldnt stand in the EU - and threatened to block another special summit to finalise a deal unless the PM made more concessions.The French president has warned that a trade deal with Britain cant come at the expense of the EUs integrity.But meddling Mr Macron launched an extraordinary attack on the leaders of the leave campaign during the referendum after the Salzburg summit.He branded Brexiteers as liars just hours after the EU tore apart Mrs Mays Brexit plans.And he said last month that Britain should for sure reverse Brexit because voters didnt realise how complex it would be.He denied meddling with British politics but said he would welcome the UK ing to the EU.However, Mr Macron has been using Brexit to his advantage - reportedly flying over top CEOs on private jets over to France for meetings.He has made no secret of his desire to nick British jobs after we leave, especially in the financial services sector which London competes fiercely with Paris for.Today EU boss Donald Tusk hit out at Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunts insulting comments comparing the EU to the Soviet Union over Brexit.But he also piled pressure on Mrs May to ditch her hated Chequers plans and go for a Canada-style free trade agreement instead.

title: prince harry meghan markle first royal tour revealed australia new zealand

title: tusk favours canada style deal
story: In a stark message the EU Council chief warned time was running out fast to strike an agreement and the PM needed to “get down to business”.He said Britain should accept the bloc’s offer of an unprecedented trade and security pact, calling it a “true sign of respect”.His remarks were met with jubilation by eurosceptics including ex-Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, who said they proved the PM’s soft Brexit plan was now a dead duck.The Polish eurocrat told Mrs May she has just two weeks to seal an exit package after holding talks with Irish leader Leo Varadkar in Brussels yesterday.He said: “From the very beginning, the EU offer has been not just a Canada deal, but a Canada plus plus plus deal.“Much further-reaching on trade, on internal security and on foreign policy cooperation.“This is a true measure of respect.And this offer remains in place.The EU is serious about getting the best possible deal.”Mr Tusk said the EU needs to see “maximum progress” at a summit starting on October the two sides are to reach a deal.He added: “Now the Tory party conference is over we should get down to business.”A key stumbling bloc to a Canada-style deal is the requirement the UK accepts a backstop that carves Northern Ireland out of its customs and regulatory sphere.But senior eurosceptics still leapt on the EU chief’s remarks and warned Mrs May she will end up with no deal at allshe perseveres with Chequers.Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson said: “Tusk’s Canada plus plus plus offer shows there is a superb way forward that can solve the Irish border problem and deliver a free trade based partnership that works well for both sides of the Channel - as I set out last week in my plan for a better Brexit.”Ex-Brexit Secretary David Davis added that it showed Downing Street was “wrong” to claim there is “no alternative to Chequers”.Referring to Mr Tusk, ex Ukip leader Nigel Farage implored the PM: “Please Mrs May, bite his hand off.”EU officials told The Sun that Mrs May will be given the chance to deliver a make-or-break pitch to leaders before they discuss Brexit over dinner.Speaking alongside the Council chief, Irish PM Leo Varadkar called for “a trading relationship with the UK after Brexit that’s as close as possible”.But just hours after his meeting with Mr Tusk the Irish PM appeared to pour cold water on the idea of a Canada-style trade deal.He said: “I don’t know what Canada plus plus plus means.It’s just a concept at this stage.He knows full well that we will not accept a deal which splits up the UK.And he also knows his comments yesterday make le more dficult for Mrs May — who he pretends to “respect”.And spare us the faux outrage about Jeremy Hunt’s comments. At least the Foreign Secretary is elected by voters, not bureaucrats.Tusk is a walking and talking reminder that we’re better off out. “There is a possibility that an agreement of that nature, which would be unique, will take more than the transition period to do.”Mr Varadkar also demanded that Britain comes up with a new backstop proposal “well in advance” of the next Council summit.And he dismissed a key possible compromise that Mrs May could offer to keep the whole of the UK in the customs union as a fallback option.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: toddler shreds 1000 cash football tickets
story: Little Leo Belnaps unsuspecting parents Ben and Jackee turned their Utah home upside down trying to find the money last weekend.They were starting to worry the envelope containing £notes had gone out with the rubbish when Jackee found it inside the shredder.Ben, of Holladay, told KSL-TV: “I’m digging through the trash and she [Jackee] hollers and says, ‘I found it.“She’s holding the shredder and she says, ‘I think the money is in here.”Jackee said she felt sick and devastated when she realised what her son had done.She said: Leo helps me shred junk mail and just things with our name on it, or important documents we want to get rid of.The mum said they had saved up the money to pay back Bens parents who had loaned them it to pay for University of Utah season tickets.Recalling that dreaded moment, she said: We just, for like five minutes, we just shuffled through it, not talking. We didnt know what to do and then I broke the silence and Im like, Well, this will make a great wedding story one day.Meanwhile Ben tried to see the funny side of it and shared a pic of a bashful Leo and the pile of torn-up cash on Twitter.He told NBC: “Most people they say oh, a kid drew crayon on the wall or something. I’ve never heard of a kid shredding a grand.”The couple have been told they might be able to get the cash backthey mail it in a ziploc bag to the US Treasury Department.Theyre told it could take two years to get the money back - and in the meantime Leo is banned from going anywhere near the shredder.

title: brexit deal very close leo varadkar
story: The blocs Brexit negotiators told national diplomats in Brussels late last night that a orce deal was almost there.Reuters UK Bureau chief Guy Faulconbridge this morning tweeted the news, hours after the Irish PM said he was hopeful a deal could be done in two weeks.The Pound got a boost against the Euro and the Dollar at the latest revelations.During talks with Brussels boss Donald Tusk last night, Mr Varadkar said it could take time to get a proper trade agreement in place, but was hopeful that a deal to sign off on the Northern Ireland border CAN be done in a fortnight.I think we are entering a critical and decisive stage of these negotiations and there is a good opportunity to clinch a deal over the next couple of weeks, he said positively.Theresa May faces a crunch summit with the other leaders of the  countries on October  and , and the clock is ticking to get an agreement signed off in time for our EU exit next March.Issues over the Northern Ireland border and what our future trade relationship with the bloc will look like have been hampering progress for months.If an agreement is reached at the October summit, Mrs May will take her deal back to MPs to vote on in the Commons within weeks.If a deal isnt signed by then, an emergency Brexit meeting in November has been pencilled in.Nothing will be sealed unless a backup plan for the Northern Ireland border can be reached.The EU want to keep Northern Ireland under the blocs customs rules after we leave, but the Prime Minister has ruled out this because it would effectively split up the UK with a border in the Irish sea.The DUP have said their lines are blood red on this - and they would withdraw their support for the PMshe betrayed them.It is understood that Mrs May is working on new plans - which could include a temporary all-UK customs union with the EU after we leave. But this could hamper Britains ability to do trade deals with other countries outside the bloc.Ireland and the UK are in a common travel area of passport-free movement.And as they are both in the EU single market, there is no restriction on goods and no tarfs.Leaders in London, Belfast, Dublin and Brussels are keen to avoid a hard border after Brexit — when the UK has vowed to leave the single market and customs union.This would mean border checks being reintroduced to monitor movement between jurisdictions operating under the two dferent regulatory systems.There were fears this could have jeopardised the Good Friday Agreement peace deal.Irish PM Leo Varadkar said he could block Brexit talks unless the UK signed a formal agreement not to have a hard border.If this happened Ireland’s businesses could be left paying tarfs on imports and exports with its biggest single trading partner, Britain.Some had suggested moving border checks across the Irish Sea — but Unionists and Brexiteers rejected that, saying it undermines the integrity of the UK.Northern Ireland parties including representatives from Sinn Fein and Alliance will meet Mr Barnier and Guy Verhofstadt today for talks in Brussels, and the DUP and UUP will have similar talks next week.But no new checks will be accepted by Theresa Mays DUP allies, Nigel Dodds said today.Its important ... that there are no economic barriers put up, tarfs, checks or anything  between one part of the United Kingdom and the other.And Irish Foreign Minister Simon COveney said that any agreement cant rely on the devolved Government because they are not currently sitting.Any agreements that are made and signed off on are between the British government and the European Union and that will be a legal text of a treaty that has to be fully legally operable, whether or not there is devolved government in Northern Ireland, he said this morning.NOT delivering on the Brexit promised to the British people would be the greatest political risk to take.The International Trade Secretary insisted that we must leave on the th of March and admitted he thought it would be possible to get a changed deal later on.He told Bloomberg: Not to deliver Brexit is the greatest political risk we could run.We should try to get as much of a final deal as we can get by the th of March, but it’s self-evident thatit’s a bilateral treaty, it can be revised later on.Negotiations are at a crunch point, with less than six months to go until Britain formally quits the EU at the end of next March.On whether Theresa May has made too many concessions to Brussels, Mr Fox said: We all had our own reservations about it, but that is the collective decision.Whilst I may be very sympathetic with those who take an ideologically purist position, we are also politicians whose job is to be able to deliver.He said that Brexiteers looking to change our EU exit didnt get that Mrs May has no majority in the House of Commons.The PMs Chequers plan has been slammed by leavers and remainers alike, but she insists theres no other deal on the cards which would keen Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK together.We have no majority in the House of Commons -- and evenwe did, that doesn’t guarantee that we have got a Leaver majority. And the reality is that we will have to get any deal through the House of Commons in the end.TODAY: Talks between the EU negotiator Michel Barnier and Northern Ireland parties Sinn Fein and Alliance get underway in Brussels.MONDAY: Mr Barnier meets with DUP politicians over the Northern Irish border. British officials work on the wording of their new offer to avoid a hard border.OCTOBER: Theresa May attends an EU Council summit where a Brexit deal is hoped to be thrashed out. Officials are still working towards this deadline.NOVEMBER: If no deal is reached in October, an emergency summit has been pencilled in for a weeks later. Both sides say this is the last chance to secure an agreement.DECEMBER: The PM will take her deal back to MPs to vote on in the House of Commons. Its expected to be a vote between her deal and no deal at all, but some MPs want to force her to renegotiate, and others are demanding another referendum.MARCH: Britain formally leaves the European Union, anda deal is done, the -month transition period will begin. This morning the Irish European Affairs Minister Helen McEntee said the will was there between both sides and she was confident that new plans to deal with the thorny issue of the Irish border would soon be revealed.She told Radio s Today programme: We have less than two weeks before the next European Council meeting, whatever the deal is, should be brought forward to Michel Barnier so we have time to look at it.I have confidence on the basis I think the Prime Minister wants to reach agreement.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: girl pulls sword lake swimming sweden
story: Saga Vanecek came across the worn weapon while she was swimming at the Vidöstern Lake in Tånnö in the south of the country.The accidental archaeologist told VN.se: “I felt something with my hand and thought it was a stick and then I lted it up and it had a handle that looked like it was a sword and then I lted it up and shouted at Dad: ‘Daddy I found a sword!’”Locals have joked that the finding of the pre-Viking blade makes Saga the “Queen of Sweden” likening her to King Arthur.In Arthurian legend the king of the Britons is handed the true Excalibur, after breaking the one he drew from the stone in battle, by the enchantress the Lady of the Lake.She found the  inch long sword on the day of the World Cup final during Europe’s scorcher of a summer which had led to the water level of the lake dropping signicantly.The low water level of the lake is the likely reason Saga managed to stumble across the sword.Sagas dad Andy Vanecek told The Local he at first thought his daughter had found a weird stick or branch in the water.It was only after he asked a pal to take a closer look that he found out it was likely to be an ancient relic.The Jönköping county museum - which is now preserving the historic item - said the sword was extremely well-preserved.Sagas discovery led the museum and local council to carry out further excavations at the site, finding a brooch from the rd Century.Mikael Nordström from the museum said: “The conservation process takes quite a long time because its a complicated environment with wood and leather, so they have several steps to make sure its preserved for the future.”The inquisitive eight-year-old only moved to Sweden last year from Minneapolis in the US so they could be closer to her mothers family.Her father added: “The cool thing is that Im a huge Minnesota Vikings fan, and this looks just like a Viking sword!”

title: nobel peace prize denis mukwege nadia murad

were also among the top ten potential winners for the prestigious prize.The International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons won last years prize.The group was recognised for “its work to draw attention to the catastrophic humanitarian consequences of any use of nuclear weapons and for its ground-breaking efforts to achieve a treaty-based prohibition of such weapons”.The Committee received nominations for  iniduals and  organisations this year.But only a few of the nominations were released as the Committee prefers to keep the majority of them secret for  years. The  prize is worth  million Swedish kronor .Past winners who came under criticism include former U.S. President Barack Obama, who won in  after less than a year in office.Thousands of people are eligible to make
