title: unilever stay uk brexit move netherlands
story: In a huge boost for Britain as we gear up to quit the EU, the consumer goods giant will remain based here after UK shareholders demanded they stay part of the FTSE  stock market.A string of influential UK investors including Aviva Investors, Columbia Threadneedle, LG, MG, Royal London and Schroders had all stated they would vote against the plans for fear of being booted out of the top index, which could drive their share price down.Unilever - which owns huge brands including Dove, Ben and Jerrys and Persil - announced the plans to relocate to the Netherlands back in March, saying they wanted to simply the business.Now Britain will keep one its biggest brand names after we quit the EU, which is valued at a whopping £billion. in.Temperatures will not exceed C or C, and it will feel cooler.Tropical Storm Leslie is currently loitering near North East Bermuda, and is set to take a southeasterly track over the coming days.This will bring with it warm rain and occasional heavy downpours.The coming week will start off chilly on Monday, with temperatures ranging from C to C across the UK.The effects of Storm Leslie will be more apparent mid-week, as temperatures creep into the mid-s by Wednesday.

title: mars bar calzone pizza takeaway glasgow
story: Described as a Glaswegian twist on the Italian food it is served with grated almonds on top of the pizza dough, caramel sauce and a scoop of chocolate ice cream.The dough is packed with Mars Bar chunks then deep fried in batter.It has been dubbed by locals as the Mars-gherita Pizza.Glaswegians have been flocking to try it the pizza, sold at Romans Pizzeria in Merchant City, Glasgow, which has an estimated , calories.Thats almost an entire days worth of calories for the average woman, and four fths for a man.The takeaway is inspired by the notorious deep-fried Mars Bar treat invented in  at a Stonehaven, Aberdeenshire, chippy - Haven Chip Bar .Romans general manager, Fraser Walker, said the idea behind the deep fried Mars Bar calzone came from a simple conversation with the head chef.The -year-old, from Kelvindale, Glasgow, said: Well the shop has been open here for about five and a half months and we wanted to bring out something dferent.This is because we are known for our Roman-style pizza, and after speaking to the chef about dferent ideas we came up with that.Weve seen restaurants adding Nutella in a calzone so we just thought the deep fried mars bar is a Scottish thing. So why not put it in a calzone Its definitely not a dessert for someone who is on a diet.Total  , caloriesI would say people should share it because its very sweet unless you have a sweet tooth or are really hungry.Costing £., the calzone has been a hit with punters, with one person even asking a relative to send a pizza to Germany.Head chef, Dawid Radzinski, said: Ive been a chef for  years and what weve done is completely original.When I first made it, we all tried it together and we all loved it. The dessert has been here since Monday and people think its really tasty.I think this was a great idea.

title: luke and ryan hart
story: On July  , their dad Lance, , ate his last supper - a ready meal paella - picked up his shotgun and drove to the local leisure centre, where he murdered his we Claire and daughter Charlotte in cold blood.With a rambling -page note in hand, in which he attempted to justy the slaughter of his family - “I had to do this… Revenge is a dish best served cold” - he then shot himself.It came as a bloody end to a campaign of abuse that lasted years, with Lance taking every chance he could to inflict emotional wounds on his family.His relentless bullying had become so bad that Luke and Ryan, now  and , had helped their -year-old sister and mum to escape from the family home, in Spalding, Lincolnshire, just days before the killings.And now the brothers - who have recently written a book about their ordeal - know the terrying truth: their evil father had been planning to butcher his entire family all along.In his murder note, Lance, a builders merchant, claimed he “had to” kill Claire because she and Charlotte had decided to leave him.But police found drafts of it on his laptop from long before they’d left the family home - a desperate move they had been forced to make five days earlier, fearing for their safety.“We want to get across that our dad didn’t kill because of a reaction to something. It wasn’t emotional. It was planned,” Ryan tells The Sun.“He was writing drafts of his murder note at least a month before we decided to move out.“So we were sitting there with him as he was typing up a note about killing us.“I think he’d always had it in the back of his mind that he would kill us when we were no longer useful to him.”“He used to march around the house at night, he says. And that’s exactly what witnesses said he did before he shot himself. So at home he was clearly trying to work himself up.”Before the day of the murder, Lance didnt physically attack his family, but he did coercively control them - taking charge of every aspect of their lives.However, it was only after they lost their mum and sister that the brothers discovered this kind of non-violent domestic abuse is more likely to turn deadly than violent domestic abuse.“We thought he’d start hitting us and we’d know this is getting lethal,” says Luke.But that never happened.The brothers childhood was spent in the Cambridgeshire countryside, living under their fathers bizarre and oppressive tyranny.“We were poor. We grew our own food. We were almost like Russian peasants,” said Luke.Lance didn’t have any friends, except on forums online, and he didn’t want Claire to have any either.But she was naturally friendly and managed to make connections in the community.Unhappy that his we was defying his control, Lance moved his family to a small village outside Spalding in Lincolnshire so fast that nobody knew where they had gone, and his behaviour escalated.Claire started working in Morrisons but he made her hand over her wages, rationing them back to her.Meanwhile she’d look after the children and complete lists of chores he’d leave round the house for her, including filling up his car - that only he drove.The one time she had a friend around he sat in the neighbouring room listening.“If he could keep her busy she had no time to see other people or build a le,” says Luke.“It was part of his isolation strategy.”Ryan remembers arbitrary rules becoming a normal aspect of their lives.“We got the bus back from school, ing at . nearly on the dot every day. Dinner was ready at ..If we were late, which we always would be, we’d be shouted at.“He wanted to find ways to attack us - whether they were legitimate or not.”The brothers realise now that their father saw them as competition.“He only ever got involved in our lives to try to hinder us,” says Ryan. “He liked humiliating us.”So the boys learned to never express an opinion or question anything.They didn’t make friends - too scared for them to come around and face Lance - and spent all their time silently doing homework.“Our le was a prison. We never had an identity,” says Luke.They were also followed around the home by their dad.“In winter we didn’t have the heating on except in the living room to force everyone in there, says Ryan.“If we moved he would sneak around and follow us, adds Luke.He would break into the toilet sometimes just to keep an eye on us.”He’d even secretly stalk Claire to her work at Morrisons, spying on her to see who she was talking to.But bright Luke and Ryan figuredthey could ace their exams it would lead to earning good salaries: a means of escape for their mum and Charlotte.After getting straight A*s, Luke went to Warwick University, and Ryan Durham, and they worked as engineers after graduating.“Going to uni was the first time ever I’d been able to relax. I realised people were actually quite nice, says Ryan. “That’s when I started to think we could live a better le.”Five days before the murders, in a terrying two-hour window before their dad came back from work for his lunch, Luke and Ryan moved Claire out of the family home into a house theyd found.“We were on edge. We knew we had to get out by  and we just made it,” says Ryan.Claire left Lance lunch and a note saying she’d left and would email him later.They’d planned to meet on Monday to exchange documents so she wasn’t surprised to see him the car park of the leisure centre - but she didnt expect him to be holding a gun.“When he realised his control had gone that’s when he decided to kill us all,” says Luke.The brothers were both away when it happened, but remember the sickening sense of dread they felt when they turned on the news.They believe the only reason he didnt kill them too was because they were away, and Luke adds that he is unsure his dad ever loved them.“I think it’s impossible to love when you hate,” he says.“And I think he always wanted to die. I think really violent men inherently become very reckless and self-destructive.”In the months after the murders, Luke started writing to process his feelings, and has now published a book, Operation Lighthouse.Named after the police’s name for the case, the book is a rallying cry for society to act on domestic abuse - and they hope it will help people recognise the signs of coercive control.However, the brothers say the emphasis shouldn’t be on the woman escaping because this can be near-impossible.“The abuser takes financial resources away, isolates you from friends and family, takes your work away, destroys your esteem and then you have nothing, explains Luke.So how do you escape  You have literally nothing. That’s the problem.Their mum and sister couldnt have been more dferent to Lance.Claire,  when she was killed, cared about other people so deeply that she had learned sign language to speak to one customer who she saw for just a few minutes a week.Charlotte, meanwhile, used to spend her time volunteering with the elderly and disabled.“They were angels and our father was evil,” says Luke.A lot of families are plagued by these behaviours eventhey’re not lethal, he adds. They still ruin people’s lives.“So we’re trying to start a conversation and make as much noise as we can.”Operation Lighthouse: Reflections on our Familys Devastating Story of Coercive Control and Domestic Homicide is out now, independently published, Amazon £..Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: infrared image hidden secret house
story: But a further investigation by an expert revealed a sweet surprise for the American owners of this brick property.David Glover aka The Bartlett Bee Whisperer had to hack into the home’s exterior in Germantown, Tennessee, to show exactly what was lurking behind the solid brick wall.A huge honeycomb – complete with thousands of honey bees – was taking up a decent chunk of the wall cavity in one of Glover’s toughest jobs.In a Facebook post, which has been shared more than , times, he admitted: “Every once in a while I get a call that makes me cringe.“Sometimes the bees are way up high, and sometimes it’s bricks.“I prefer to be minimally invasive when removing honey bees from buildings. I don’t like taking out bricks.“Will the mortar chip out, or will the bricks crumble  Will the [honey] combs be usable once the bricks are out of the way  As much as I dreaded removing the bricks the final view of the hive was AWESOME!“The homeowner was more than pleased that we were able to remove and relocate the bees and their hive.”Incredible images and video footage helped the beekeeper identy where the bees may be living before proving it with an infrared picture and then starting to remove the bricks.As he removed more bricks he began to uncover a huge honeycomb beneath a window, which remained intact.After safely removing it, Glover pointed out the stain left behind by thousands of tiny bee feet walking on the white surface.He explained to Bored Panda: “Step-by-step the area of the home is opened, and all combs removed. Brood combs are rubber banded into hive frames and honey goes into a bucket .“If the homeowner is willing to eat a piece of comb with me, it’s probably never been sprayed. The bees who do not follow the combs into the new hive box are vacuumed into a two-stage vacuum. They are added back to the new hive once they are set up in their new yard.After the Bee Whisperer rescues bees, he uses them to repopulate empty hive boxes for local beekeepers who have suffered colony losses.He added: “No one is aware of the size of their honey bee hive. They are all surprised because they are expecting something the size of a wasp nest or hornet’s nest.“The infrared gives them the first clue, but that’s only the brood combs of the hive.The babies are incubated at . degrees Celsius. Any honey combs in the hive are cooler and usually don’t show on the IR.”

title: asshat douchebaggery and fam among 1400 new phrases added to oxford dictionary sparking controversy
story: Other controversial additions, which were announced today, include douchebaggery, asshat, updation and Pooh-sticks.A surprising number of slang words have also made it into the dictionary - most notably the phrase bump and grind, which OED describes as a dancers erotic gyration of the hips.Among the slang words set to appear on the pages of the dictionary is butters, an adjective commonly used to describe someone or something as ugly.Another on the list is bum-suck, which is a colloquialism for a brown nose or suck up. Crip-walk - a dance invented by the US-based Crip gang in the s - has also been added.And the word ducket - slang for money - is now included in the official list of words used in the English language.By far the most controversial new entry is the word fam, short for family.It was first seen as graphic abbreviation in the th century but only started to be used as slang in the s in the US hip hop scene.OEDs head of US dictionaries Katherine Connor Martin said it has now been adopted in the UK, especially in London.She said: The original meaning of family was soon extended to people who were not ones actual relatives, but rather close friends or fellow members of a particular group, and it became common as a form of direct address , either to a single person or to many.But the changes have not gone unnoticed by Brits, who have taken to social media to challenge OED.One user tweeted: Fam  Are you kidding me  Another gobsmacked user wrote: Fam is becoming a word. Fam is becoming and actual word.Others took issue with the word updation. Please get rid of updation, one man requested.Updation is defined as the action or act of updating something. Ms Martin said it was a nominalisation of the verb update.

title: queen moving buckingham palace refurbishment private rooms
story: Britains longest reigning monarch will have to switch suites as part of a refit of the building to prevent a catastrophic disaster such as a fire or a flood, a senior royal official said today.Three thousand items including  paintings,  chandeliers and  mirrors will be removed before wiring and pipes are replaced.The works, which started in spring last year, have led to , metres of dangerous vulcanised rubber cabling being ripped out in a bid to ward off a potentially catastrophic failure.Towards the end of the project, the -year-old monarch and her husband Prince Philip, , will have to move out of their apartments in the palaces north wing for about two years when work starts there in .The queen is immensely pragmatic and she wants to stay in the palace, the official told reporters. She said let me know where you would like me to go.The Prince of Wales is said to be fully engaged with the project, while the Duke of Edinburgh is also keeping a close eye on developments.Mr Johnstone-Burt said: We all take the responsibility that comes with using public funds to do all this work on such a national icon like Buckingham Palace extremely seriously indeed.... on time, within budget and to the required specication.Work is now underway to empty the famous East Wing, the public facade of the building which includes the balcony on which the royal family appears on special occasions.Next week, a compound for  contractors will be erected on the forecourt to one side of the building but the palace will remain fully open for state visits and other regular events.I am absolutely convinced that by making this investment in the palace now, we will... avert a much more costly and potentially catastrophic failure of the building in the years to come, he said.The emptying of the East Wing will mean three of the queens four children - Princess Anne, Prince Andrew and Prince Edward - moving their offices. Heir-to-the-throne Prince Charles will be unaffected as his London home is at nearby Clarence House.Tim Knox, Director of the Royal Collection, said some of these items would go on public display at other palaces while  objects wouldto the Royal Pavilion in Brighton, George IVs bizarre seaside home on the south coast of England from where they were moved in  when that residence was sold.Buckingham Palace was built in  as a large private home and was only acquired by the monarch, King George III, in .The East Wing was part of an extension built in the reign of Queen Victoria. The front facade was refaced in  in harder-wearing Portland stone when George V - Elizabeths grandfather - was on the throne.

title: kitkatclub berlin bacterial meningitis
story: Dozens of clubbers who visited the KitKatClub have been tested and many others are being urged to get checked immediately.It comes after one person contracted meningitis at the downtown club on Saturday night, officials said.The KitKatClub is renowned for its sexually uninhibited techno parties that draw visitors from around the world.City authorities issued a warning this week after being alerted to the Berlin patrons exposure to the disease.Bacterial meningitis can be spread via saliva and close body contact.Common symptoms are strong headaches, high fever, a stf neck, dizziness and weakness.The disease can become le-threatening within hours.In a statement on Facebook, the club said while infections in the club were very unlikely according to doctors and authorities.Anybody suffering from symptoms should immediately see a doctor.The club said that none of its employees had shown any symptoms so far, but all had been offered antibiotics as a preventive measure.City officials said there was no need to shut down the club because it wasnt the source of infection, and the site itself was not contaminated.

title: central line tube strikes latest friday time end
story: Other underground lines are also likely to be affected by the -hour driver walkout as trains become packed with workers clocking off after a week in the office.All services on the Central Line are down as members of the Aslef union walked out in a dispute over industrial relations after last ditch talks to halt the strike failed.Around a third of London Underground services have been cancelled, with more disruption due on Saturday.RMT members on Arriva Rail Northwill strike for  hours tomorrow in the same dispute.Angry commuters have blasted service providers online. On Twitter, MarkHGrainger said: There are people out there that would looking these guys jobs. Sack the lot of them. They making people hate them.Jo Offord blasted: Stop bullying innocent members of the public by withdrawing their ability to get to work. Treat the public with respect. #centrallineAnd Daian added: I bet these people just go on strike for a day off. I mean come on trains are automated anyways, the driver doesnt even do anything. This is crippling, destructive behaviour. The central line is vital to the city. #TubeStrikeThe strike will also hit services on the Waterloo and City Line, which links Waterloo with the City of London.Union leaders say this is due to a breakdown of industrial relations in a long-running dispute with the London Underground.They say Tube bosses have imposed unsafe working practices.The RMT said its survey of the safety role played by guards was backed up by new British Transport Police figures which showed a % surge in violence on Britains railways.The union surveyed  guards, with four out of five saying they had prevented an emergency situation and used their safety-critical training in an actual emergency.Half had prevented at least one sexual assault and % have dealt with anti-social behaviour.RMT general secretary Mick Cash said: In contrast to the cost-cutting plans and misleading propaganda dreamt up in Whitehall and the rail boardrooms, this survey shows the reality of the vital role train guards play at the sharp end to ensure a safe, secure and accessible railway.In their own words, these dedicated rail workers are warning of the horric consequences of there no longer being a guard to provide assistance and to help deal with emergencies, violent behaviour, sexual assaults and the terrorist threat.Unsurprisingly, % of guards in our survey felt the main reason companies are introducing driver-only trains is to increase profits, with the same number saying the Government is on side of the train companies and not passengers.Its time the Government and rail bosses stopped thinking about the bottom line and listened to voices of rail workers delivering on the front line.Rachael Maskell, shadow transport minister, said: The spike in crime on our railways, including a sharp rise in sexual offences, underlines the importance of a properly staffed railway to keep passengers and employees safe.Labour has warned the Government of the risks posed by the expansion of driver-only operation and todays figures show why the de-staffing of trains and stations must be halted immediately.

title: tourist bali raw markets red dragon massage
story: Matthew Raison asked for a red dragon treatment on the sixth day of his Bali holiday with we Candise.The masseur reportedly asked Matthewhe wanted to get the red dragon out of him.He went on to carve the power line technicians back with a coin, insisting his body will become a red dragon.And the next day, Matthews back was covered in huge red marks from the top of his neck to his tailbone.Incredible pictures show the raw lines span the width of his body.Candise, from Paringa in South Australia, said: My husband will try anything.Fair to say we were all in tears of laughter.She said Matthew has been complained of back problems for the past three years.But, since the gua sha massage, Candise told Mail Online: He hasn’t complained about a sore back now.He said it felt like an itch waiting to be itched, and then when it finally got scratched it was fantastic.

title: postman urinates doorstep delivering mail tennessee
story: Scott Anderson was shocked when his doorbell camera caught the postman brazenly relieving himself on his property in broad daylight on Monday.The outrageous clip captures the United States Postal Serviceemployee leave a trail of urine in his wake as he makes his way up to the mailbox in Memphis, Tennessee.Yet he brazenly posts the mail in the porch.Scott has yet to pick up his letters as he fears what could be left on them.The homeowner said: I check [my cameras] every time I get a notication on my phone.He reported the vile act to USPS.A spokesman for the agency said: “We are investigating the actions of our letter carrier revealed in the video.“This behaviour clearly does not reflect the efforts of the thousands of professional, dedicated carriers in our workforce.“We are reaching out to the homeowner to offer our apology and assistance in dealing with this issue.“The Postal Service will take appropriate corrective action to address the situation with this employee.“As a matter of policy, we are unable to comment further on specic personnel matters.”The USPS is a government agency responsible for providing the postal service across the nation.The body was founded in  in Washington DC.

title: danny boyle calls for beaches tribute for armistice centenary
story: Speaking as he launched the Pages Of The Sea project in Folkestone, he said: "The idea was to come to the beach and create a work of art, and to say goodbye to all the people who left from these beaches a hundred years ago."Were going to create a vast, huge portrait on the beach of the particular person thats picked for reasons of connection to a local community."On this beach, its Wilfred Owen, the greatest poet of World War I, who left from this harbour for France, who swam in this water apparently the day before he left for France."After Boyles stunning success organising the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in London in , it is hoped he will once again capture the mood of the nation. He says he hopes his latest project, which will also see a poem by Carol Ann Duffy being read out by iniduals, families and communities as they gather on the beaches, will compliment the more formal commemorations being organised to mark the day the Great War ended."It was a great privilege, an incredible experience to do it ," he said. "Most of that experience is about the volunteers who came to the stadium and rehearsed and made the show, really."This is sort of it in reverse - were going to the communities, to their places and hope that they turn up with the same spirit." Boyle, famous for films including Trainspotting, The Beach and Slumdog Millionaire, was tasked with the project by - Now, a programme of arts commissions marking the First World War centenary which has enlisted more than  artists over the last five years.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey"" data-targeting-"" data-tag"" data-component-name"sdc-site-mpu" aria-label"Advertisement" id"mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance""

title: nobel peace prize goes to denis mukwege and nadia murad
story: At just -years-old Ms Murad became the UNs first goodwill ambassador for the dignity of survivors of human trafficking after speaking openly about what she suffered before she escaped Islamic State.The committee said: "She has shown uncommon courage in recounting her own sufferings and speaking up on behalf of other victims."Nadia Murad is one of an estimated , Yazidi girls and women who were victims of rape and other abuses by the IS army. "The abuses were systematic and part of a military strategy. They served as a weapon in the fight against Yazidis and other religious minorities."Dr Mukwege has repeatedly condemned impunity for mass rape in the country, and criticised the Congolese government and other countries for not doing enough to stop the use of sexual violence against women as a weapon of war, the Nobel committee said."Denis Mukweges basic principle is that justice is everyones business," it said."The  Peace Laureate is the foremost, most unying symbol, both nationally and internationally, of the struggle to end sexual violence in war and armed conflicts." The nine million Swedish kronorprize will be shared between the two laureates.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey"" data-targeting-"" data-tag"" data-component-name"sdc-site-mpu" aria-label"Advertisement" id"mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance""

title: smirking harvey weinstein refuses to apologise one year on
story: In the flesh he is a shadow of the confident, burly character that once ruled Hollywood.The man who strutted the red carpets is now pale and hobbles as he walks.He was surrounded by security guards but we got right up to him.I asked him whether the nearly  women who had accused him of harassment and assault were lying.He said nothing.I asked himhe was ashamed.He said nothing.I asked whether he had anything to say to the women who have accused him.He said nothing.But he did grin and say "thank you very much" before getting into the back of an SUV before being driven off.He seemed, well, kind of small.Maybe thats because as he prepares for a criminal trial, the international movement he unwittingly helped spark is reflecting on a year of seismic change.

title: unilever shareholders bared their teeth and won
story: There were other criticisms, too. Unilever got the fright of its le when, in February last year, US food giant Kraft Heinz approached it about a bn takeover. This restructuring was seen as a way for the company, which has a Dutch chairman and chief executive, to avoid such incidents in future because the Netherlands has tougher takeover laws than the City. Mark Rutte, the Dutch prime minister and a former Unilever employee, did his bit to smooth the way by promising to abolish a tax on idends that made holding the shares in the UK more attractive than in the Netherlands.One by one, the big battalions of City fund managers, many of whom prefer to speak on an anonymous basis to the financial press, broke cover to say what a dreadful idea this was: Colombia Threadneedle, Lindsell Train, Schroders, Aviva Investors, MG and Royal London all publicly stated their opposition. With Unilever needing the backing of % of UK investors to go ahead with the reorganisation, it was starting to look like a close-run thing.Yet that was not the only dficulty that emerged for the consumer goods giant.The influential Financial Times columnist Neil Collins, the most vocal critic of the move from the start, spotted in the small print of the particulars sent to investors that Unilever also required a simple majority of shareholders taking part in the vote for the motion to be passed. In other words, a small shareholder with only a handful of shares would carry as much weight as a big City institution with millions of them.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey"" data-targeting-"" data-tag"" data-component-name"sdc-site-mpu" aria-label"Advertisement" id"mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance""

title: eu chief jean claude juncker
story: NewsEU chief Jean-Claude Juncker blasts warring Tories for leaving him to pick up the pieces of BrexitThe EU Commission President complained that Brussels was being left to “arrange the pieces” of the split at the top of GovernmentShareByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  OCT NewsTheresa May’s warring Cabinet are to blame for Brexit isions, Jean-Claude Juncker claimed "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May’s warring Cabinet are to blame for Brexit isions, Jean-Claude Juncker claimed today. The EU Commission President complained that Brussels was being left to “arrange the pieces” of the split at the top of Government.But EU sources suggested a Brexit deal was “very close” as the clock counts down to the deadline.Mr Juncker told Austria’s parliament: “Negotiations are not easy because we also have to be critical that we receive dferent signals from London. “There is a polyphonic chorus at the level of the British Cabinet and we try to arrange the pieces ... so that they become a melody.” His comments will fuel tensions in the run-up to this month’s crunch showdown where EU leaders will bid to thrash out a UK exit plan.  Bloc chiefs hope to strike a deal in Brussels in less than two weeks, before rubber-stamping the pact at a one-off meeting in November. Mr Juncker hoped October’s European Council summit would make “enough progress” that “we can see it through in November”. No deal would be “devastating”, he added. Mrs May was under mounting pressure tonight to bring forward plans to break the deadlock over the Northern Ireland border. Dublin’s Europe Minister Helen McEntee was confident a deal could be struck, but warned negotiations were reaching a “critical point”. Mrs May rejected the EU’s proposal for a “backstop” to prevent a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic after Brexit.

story: NewsDavid Davis used to think colourful ties were gay claims Tory MPs former chief of staffThe revealing comment emerged in an anecdote on Good Morning Britain about the former Brexit SecretaryShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror tv tv-news video iain-dale-on-david-davis-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory MP David Davis used to think colourful ties were gay, his former chief of staff has said. The revealing comment emerged in an anecdote on ITVs Good Morning Britain about the former Brexit Secretary - who lost the Tory leadership race to David Cameron in . Broadcaster Iain Dale - the Conservatives first openly gay candidate who was Davis chief of staff for six months around the vote - said: When I worked for David Davis, he had a terrible taste in ties. Hed always wear really old-men stripy ties.  I wore at that point quite colourful Duchamp ties, and Id say to him for goodness sake, wear one of these! And hed say, But Im not gay!. title: universal credits next stage could
story: NewsUniversal Credits next stage could spark a huge increase in people being forced to rely on food banksThe Trussell Trust have warned issues with benefits are the main reason for referrals to receive emergency food suppliesShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsIt could spark a huge increase, the Trussell Trust warn "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe next stage of Universal Credit could spark a huge increase in food bank use, a charity warned today. The Trussell Trust, which runs more than  foodbanks across the UK, said issues with benefits were the main reason for referrals to receive emergency food supplies. Waiting for the first payment and moving to the new system are blamed for causing hardship. It comes as as the Department for Work and Pensions finalises its plans for the next stage of the benefits shake-up to put before MPs later this month. Until now, only people making a new application for benefits in certain areas have been able to apply for Universal Credit.  This next stage - ‘managed migration’ - will see the three million people currently receiving tax credits or benefit payments under the old system sent a letter telling them to reapply for these payments under Universal Credit. Each person will have to wait at least five weeks for the first payment, andpeople miss the deadline for application, could face having all their payments stopped. Emma Revie, Chief Executive of the Trussell Trust said: “It doesn’t have to be like this. We know the problems people are likely to face as they move over to the new system, so we can learn from them.  The Department for Work and Pensions has shown they can act on evidence from the frontline to make a real dference to people who need our benefits system’s vital support. Now is the time for our Government to take responsibility for moving people currently on the old system over, and to ensure no one faces a gap in payments when that moves happens. Universal Credit needs to be ready for anyone who might need its help, and it needs to be ready before the next stage begins.”

title: what happens next brexit theresa
story: NewsWhat happens next with Brexit: Is Theresa Mays Chequers plan dead  Can a deal with the EU be reached and will there be another general election The Brexit negotiations reach their endgame in the next few weeks. This is your guide to what could happen nextShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email We are nearing the moment of truth. In the next few weeks the Brexit negotiations will reach their final stage.Can Theresa May strike a deal  And,so, what happens then The Prime Minister still has to reach a compromise with Brussels on her unloved Chequers plan .Then she has to present the deal to Parliament for MPs’ approval. The stakes could not be higher. Hundreds of thousands of jobs, our national security and economic well-being depend on what happens. Any  step by the Prime Minister and it could spell the end of her time in office. Here’s your guide to a crucial few weeks: What is the next stage   Britain and the EU will resume the Brexit negotiations next week after the stalemate at Salzburg.At the Austrian summit Mrs May’s Chequers plan was bluntly rejected as unworkable.The EU said it did not resolve the Irish border issue and her trade proposals gave Britain access to EU markets without having to abide by the rules on free movement of goods, people and services. Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab is expected to travel to Brussels on Monday to try to break the deadlock. On Wednesday  the President of the EU Jean-Claude Juncker is scheduled to make a declaration on the future trading relationship with the UK. Many believe he will offer the UK a Canada +++with a carve out on Northern Ireland. When will a decision be made   Mrs May will join EU leaders on Wednesday  for a working dinner on Brexit, migration and foreign policy. The following day will be the moment of truth. This is when we will discoverboth sides have found a way to resolve their dferences and have the basis for a potential agreement. If there a deal is in the offing then there will be another summit, pencilled in for November , to sign it off. How could the deadlock be broken   The simple answer is through a large amount of fudge and kicking the contentious issues into the long grass.Theresa May could agree to stick to EU rules on trade and goods to allow the UK to stay in a customs union after the transition period ends in .This would give us more time to bring in the technology needed to allow for frictionless trade across borders. But this would limit our ability to strike independent trade deals - the main prize in the eyes of the Brexiteers of our leaving. To resolve the Irish border question Britain could agree for Northern Ireland to have dferent regulations from the rest of the UK with the checks on goods taking place away from ports, borders and airports.This will require the agreement of the DUP which has been adamant there can be no border in the Irish Sea. Theresa May is expected to presents her plans to Parliament at the end of November or early December. MPs have been offered a meaningful vote on the final deal. What happens depends on who is best at counting. Labour has signalled it would vote down any deal unless it meets all six of its demands.The question for Jeremy Corbyn is what happensMrs May brings back a package which is within a whisker of passing his party’s six tests.The ultimate prize for the Labour leader is for Parliament to vote down Mrs May’s deal paving the way for a general election. But Mr Corbyn has to weigh up the cost of being seen to block what voters may regard as a sensible deal. If Labour does vote against the agreement the Prime Minister will have to rely on a handful of Labour Brexiteers to get it over the line.But they could be outweighed by the diehard Tory Brexiteers who have vowed to block Chequers including Jacob Rees-Mogg , Boris Johnson and Owen Paterson.There is also a risk that one or two Tory remainer MPs may side with Labour. Allies of Mrs May are still confident she can get a deal through Parliament. They believe that when forced to make a decision Tory Brexiteers would rather swallow the Prime Minister’s offering which they can unpick later than risk losing the prize of Brexit altogether. Tory remainers could also drop their objections rather than unleash the chaos which could lead to Jeremy Corbyn coming to power. What we do know is that when the vote comes the numbers will be nail-bitingly tight. What happensthe deal is voted down by Parliament   The short answer is nobody knows. Theresa May would be under immense pressure to resign. MPs would have to conjour up a motion that called on the Prime Minister to go back to the negotiating table.With time running out we would also have to ask for an extension of Article  which set the timetable for our departure.Extending Article  requires the unanimous approval of all  other EU states. They are likely to agree rather than allow the UK to crash out without a deal but we don’t know what price,any, they will demand for such a favour. The EU would have us over a barrel: the options would be the economically ruinous crashing out with no deal or bowing to Brussels in order to get an extension. Could we have another election or a second referendum

story: NewsDevastating messages parents found scrawled in girls secret diary after she took her own leDean and Alysia Valoras hope that sharing the story of daughter Alexandra will help save livesShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience WriterRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAlexandra Valoras was just  when she died"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAlexandra Valoras was an ambitious high achiever at school and her parents always thought she acted responsibly. Thats why they didnt immediately panic when they woke up on the morning of March  to find that the -year-old wasnt in her room.Tracking the GPS on her phone, they traced her location to a nearby overpass about a mile away from their family home in Grafton, Massachusetts, the Boston Globe reported.Dad Dean and mum Alysia drove with younger daughter Emily to the bridge where the location indicated Alexandra, or at least her phone, was. They noticed some of her stuff nearly piled on a concrete pylon: her boots, jacket, water bottle and two notebooks. I leaned over the embankment and looked down, and I saw her, said Dean Valoras, her father, to CBS news .I was just hoping for warmth. Do you know what I mean  But there was no warmth, there was none. And all the cars kept driving by. My daughters on the side of the road, nobody saw this. And shes cold. Inside the journals the family discovered on the bridge were pages and pages of desperation and self-loathing - a contrast between her interior and exterior worlds. She had written things like you are broken, you are a burden, you are lazy and you are a failure.  There was just so much joy in everything she did, and it doesnt match what was in that journal, mum Alysia said. Alexandra had begun her diary entries less than a year before. Her scrawled entries revealed the extraordinarily high standards she held herself to and the facade the teenager said she used as a shell to hide behind. In her final journal entry, just hours before she killed herself, Alexandra wrote: Dont blame yourselves for not seeing warning signs. I hid for a reason. I didnt want you to know how deep in my own mess I was. She slipped out of the house in the night and walked to the nearby bridge, after months of silently weighing up taking her own le in her writing.

story: NewsBoy, , lost legs and seven fingers after climbing on train wagon near , volt overhead cablesA company has now been found guilty of a safety breach after the schoolboy was set on fire during the horric incident at a Tyne Yard railway depot in GatesheadShareByBy Rob KennedyKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT NewsThe boy caught on fire at the rail yard "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old boy had both legs and seven fingers amputated after climbing on top of a train wagon near ,-volt overhead cables. The boy and three friends had been able to easily gain access to a Tyne Yard railway depot, in Gateshead, which was a common haunt for youngsters. A company has now been found guilty of a safety breach after the schoolboy was set on fire and lost his legs and seven fingers following a rail yard electrocution. A jury found freight operator DB Cargo guilty of failing to protect people from risk, Chronicle Live reports.  A disused signal box known as the “haunted house” was a popular attraction to children at the site, near Birtley, and prosecutors said inadequate measures were in place to keep people off the premises. When two lads began climbing up a wagon, one of them got too close to the live overhead wire and suffered catastrophic injuries. During the trial at Newcastle Crown Court, prosecutor Gordon Menzies said the railway yard was a potentially hazardous area by nature but added: “It was made much more dangerous by the fact that in this yard, on the defendant’s land which it leased from Network Rail, there was a signal box which had not been used since . “It had a reputation among local children and was known as the haunted house. It was something of a lure to not just young children but older children as well.  “The prosecution say the dangers those children were exposed to arise because of the inadequacies of the defendant’s arrangements for keeping that site secure. “It was a hazardous area and was left insecure.” The court heard access to the yard, which is off the East Coast Mainline, could be gained by four bridges off Lamesley Road, near Birtley. Two of them had been safely fenced off but the third had a gate which did not lock properly, while a fourth did not have any gate to prevent pedestrian access, Mr Menzies said. On Saturday June  , two boys and two girls aged between  and , who cannot be named for legal reasons, went to the yard to go to the signal yard. DB Cargo had denied failing to ensure non-employees, including the four children, were not exposed to risk. Mr Menzies told jurors: “There was not a single fence or credible obstacle to prevent them getting to the haunted house and being exposed to the risks that were involved.Mums terror of dragging her children out of bed after home was set on fire in arson attack“There was no security patrol present, there weren’t even any warning signs on the bridge to provide even that minimal level of deterrent. “The prosecution say this was an obvious trespassing route.” After spending time in the signal box, the children began to explore the yard and played on large piles of rubble. The two boys started to climb up a railway wagon in the sidings and one reached the top but suffered an electric shock after getting too close to the overhead cables. It is not necessary to even touch them in order to get an electric shock, jurors heard. His -year-old friend behind him also suffered an electric shock and was thrown to the ground but escaped with minor injuries. Mr Menzies said: “The children described a loud bang andwas thrown to the ground. “ was set on fire and fell to the ground. “He suffered le-changing injuries, including the amputation of both of his legs, one above he knee, one below, and all the fingers and thumb on his right hand, and on his left hand two fingers and part of his left hand itself.”  Prosecutors said DB Cargo did not do enough to ensure people were not exposed to risk. One of the youngsters said for a time she would go there every day and prosecutors say the signal box was a “den”, which the company denies. DB Cargo had arranged security patrols of the signal box but only at night on weekdays, the court heard. It also put up warning signs but pictures showed these had been ripped off. Its own risk assessments showed it was a high risk environment, the court heard. Referring to the children going to the sidings, Mr Menzies said: “There was nothing to stop them, no security guards, none of the staff stopped them, there’s no CCTV in that area. “They were able to roam about half a mile from where they entered the site.”

story: NewsFantasist posed as woman to lure straight men into having sex with him wearing blindfoldDepraved Duarte Xavier, , trawled dating sites masquerading as Ana where he chatted to scores of heterosexual men and sent them saucy photosShareBySam Corbishley:,  OCT NewsXavier invited men to his flat under the pretence he was a woman named Ana "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA fantasist who posed as a woman on dating apps to lure men into having sex with him is facing years behind bars. When they agreed to meet up, Ana set a series of conditions they had to abide by, including a stipulation that they wear a blindfold throughout the liaison. That victim reported the incident to police and Xavier was arrested on October   on suspicion of causing sexual activity with a person without consent. But he was released under investigation. A number of mobile phones and masks were also seized. The third incident took place on April  this year when -year-old Ana lured another man to her darkened flat where she claimed to be concealing her identity so as not to tip off her husband to the fact she was having an affair. story: NewsTourist gets red dragon massage but is shocked to discover what that really meansMatthew and Candise Raison, from Australia, were on holiday in Bali when they decided to treat themselves to a massage but he got more than he bargained forShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAustralian tourist Matthew Raison was left with raised red marks on his back after getting a red dragon massage in Bali"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA tourist was left shocked when he opted for what he thought was a relaxing red dragon massage but was left huge red marks across his back. Matthew and Candise Raison, from Australia, were on holiday in Bali along with his sister Tamzin when they decided to get a relaxing massage. They opted for a go jek massage where the masseur comes to you as the ultimate holiday treat. But Matthew didnt know what the masseur meant when he askedhe wanted him to get the red dragon out of him.  Speaking to Daily Mail Australia, Candise said her husband thought the masseur was trying some prayer thing. She told him: I dont know what youre saying but my husband will try anything, go for it! However, they soon found out what the masseur really meant as he started to carve into Matthews back with a coin. The massage is called Gua sha which is an Asian medical practice where the side of a coin is rubbed in parallel stripes on the chest and back. Its often referred to as scraping or coining and is believed to release unhealthy body matter from sore, tired, or injured muscles and stimulate new, oxygenated blood flow.  The red marks ran from the top of his neck all the way down to his tailbone. Despite looking like he had been hurt with the red raised marks covering his back, Matthew and Candise saw the funny side. Its fair to say we were all in tears of laughter, she said. Despite the unsightly appearance, the massage brought Matthew some relief from his chronic back pain. Candise said her husband, who works on power lines, has had a sore back for almost three years.

title: can roarie be dundees deacon of hope
story: Former Arsenal kid Roarie Deacon’scoincided with Dundee’s first league victory of the season – could he be the piece that’s been missing from their Premiership jigsaw The -year-old, who signed from English National League side Sutton United last summer, has missed the entire start of the season after having ankle surgery.Picking up the injury in the final game of last season, the enigmatic attacker ed for the final six minutes of the club’s first league win of the season – at the seventh time of the asking – at Hamilton and, in the process, set up the second goal.And hiswas hailed by manager Neil McCann.He said: “Roarie Deacon I am really pleased about getting back in because we have suffered some real injury problems of late.“He hadn’t featured at all, he’d only had  minutes of football all season before Saturday but I knew putting him on he could secure the ball because he is so strong.“You can’t get close to Roarie and he turned the boy beautully, then he had the composure.“I have to commend the other boys as well because they were still trying to get into the box at that stage to get the killer goal.”Deacon himself was delighted to be back in action after his y spell out.A process that was extended after an older injury reared its head once more.His debut season was also curtailed by injury with a troublesome thigh problem picked up in December at Hearts keeping him out of action for a big chunk of the middle of the campaign.And, on histo training this season, he hurt the same thigh once more.Deacon said: “I had ankle surgery the first week into pre-season.“I twisted it and damaged ankle ligaments in the game against Partick and through the summer it didn’t heal itself.“The surgeon didn’t want to operate initially but it didn’t heal itself so we made the decision to go under the kne to sort it out.“I was supposed to be back a little earlier than this but on the first session back I re-injured my thigh, a problem I had last season, so I needed a bit of intense rehabilitation on that to get back.“Now, though, I am ready to go and I’m fit.”With goals being a real issue for the side – just four scored in their seven league games and half of them against Accies at the weekend – Deacon’sis a timely boost for the Dark Blues.In fact, he’s only played around six minutes this season but has already had a hand in a quarter of their league goals.Coming into the side struggling for goals and points, though, hasn’t ruffled Deacon in any way.And Dundee fans will be hoping his direct running and ability to go past people is the key that unlocks defences with tough matches against Kilmarnock on Saturday and then Livingston, Hearts and Celtic in the next month.The former Sutton man admits he’s surprised the Dark Blues find themselves bottom of the table as he s to fitness and has backed them to get up the table,they keep doing what they’ve been doing.He added: “I am very surprised, everyone is surprised.“No way we thought we would come in, do well in pre-season, and then come in and after six games not have a point on the board.“However, after Hamilton everyone is positive, you can’t not be because the way we’ve been playing it’s not like we’ve not created chances or played well despite not getting points.“Everyone is buzzing about in training, raring to go and wanting to do well for Dundee.”

title: embarrassed freddy frans confident dundee united can recover
story: Dundee United defender Freddy Frans admits he felt embarrassed to have led the side during their - home defeat at the hands of Ross County which, ultimately, spelled the end for Csaba Laszlo.Frans captained the side on the day as Csaba was relieved of his duties as manager in the wake of the Tannadice hammering.His No  Laurie Ellis has taken interim charge and will likely be in the dugout as United travel to Somerset Park to face league leaders Ayr United on Saturday.And, although he is still hurting after the County calamity, Belgian centre-back Frans believes they can bounce back straight away.“People should look at themselves, we don’t need to talk about somebody , we don’t need to talk about the manager or other players,” he said.“We need to look at our own performances and I feel embarrassed.“Especially in an important game like this against one of our title rivals. I can’t remember getting beaten like this.“At half-time there was a lot of emotion, we were trying to get things straight and after the game we’re angry but what can you say  We need to look at ourselves.“It’s easy to look at others and pass the blame on but there is no use in doing that.“We need to stick together.“You always have to be confident, it’s stupid as a football player to think you can’t turn it around. You have to stay positive.“Even though it’s hard to take we have to take it on the chin and go again this weekend.”The -year-old was at a loss to explain what went wrong on Saturday as a Billy Mckay hat-trick and goals from Sean Kelly and Joshua Mullin did the damage for a United side that could only muster one of their own through Pavol Safranko on  minutes.What Frans did accept though, was they need to improvethey want to get the better of the likes of Ross County and others now above them in the race for the Championship title.The Terrors lie in fourth, five points behind leaders Ayr and Frans feels they can learn a thing or two from their promotion rivals.“Sometimes it’s hard to explain in football, you get so much confidence and then this happens. It comes from nowhere,” he added.“I think we started really well. We had a great chance at the beginning and, obviously, we miss it. We concede a stupid goal on a set-piece where we need to be smarter.“We get back into the game with a great goal and, in that moment, I thought we were OK but again we concede a stupid goal again with a cross from the side.“Even then at - it’s bad but I thought ‘look we’ve got  minutes to turn it round’ and then we concede quite early.“The red card for Stewart Murdoch finished it. It’s easy to blame it on mentality but with the goals we conceded it’s about quality as well.“It’s about being smart. That’s what theydid better on Saturday, they were more dirty, more street-wise and we’re too nice.“I can’t blame boys, especially during the week in training, for effort because we train really hard butyou see the game on Saturday it’s logical for the first thing people question to be mentality.“You can run as much as you want butyou don’t do the basics and take a hold of the ball,you don’t pick up your man, simple things like that you’ll lose the game.”Frans apologised to fans, saying: “There’s not much we can say to the supporters, just sorry. I know it’s cheap to say but there is no excuse. We’re just sorry.”

title: give laurie ellis the managers job permanently says dundee united legend john holt
story: Tangerine legend John Holt believes the Dundee United board do not have to leave Tannadice to find the perfect successor to Csaba Laszlo.The man who won the Premier League and two League Cups with United believes caretaker boss Laurie Ellis is the man to take over on a permanent basis.John remains a regular at home matches through his work in the Tannadice hospitality lounges and was sad to see Csaba sacked but believes after a dficult start to the season that the - weekend loss to Ross County made his departure inevitable.“You never like to see a manager sacked and I feel sorry for Csaba, I really do, but it’s been clear for a while now things haven’t been working.“Saturday was another bad home defeat and, for any manager,the team isn’t performing in front of their own fans it’s a big problem.“After the fourth goal I’d say between , and , fans just got up and left. You can’t have that. I know United are not where they want to be right now but even so you can’t have that kind of defeat at a club this size.”“Holtie” was pleased to see Ellis put in interim charge after the manager was sacked on Sunday but feels the way forward was a permanent appointment there and then.“I’ve spoken to Laurie a few times now and he comes across as someone who knows what he’s talking about and how to get the best out of players.“That’s what United need right now because they’ve a decent squad, it’s just that Csaba wasn’t getting the best out of them.“Laurie’s still young and it would be his first job as a manager, but with an experienced No  I think he’d be a success.“He’s got a steely edge to him but he gets along with people. He’d be good with you boys in the press and unlike in my day that’s important for a manager.”If Ellis doesn’t get the nod, the former favourite knows who he’d like to see the club turn to but accepts his second choice may not be heading back to Scotland any time soon.“Billy McKinlay is someone who’d do a great job. ‘Badger’ is a respected coach and he’s someone who knows his stuff.“I think the problem with him would be the level he’s been operating at down in England and where.”

title: jim mcinally backs former dundee united teammate to take over as manager
story: Jim McInally believes a former team mate would be the best choice as Dundee United’s new manager.The Tangerines are searching for a replacement for Csaba Lazlo.But Tannadice legend McInally would plump for Billy McKinlay, who made  appearances for United and has worked as a coach with Roy Hodgson at Fulham and David Moyes at Real Sociedad, Sunderland and West Ham.McInally, now Peterhead boss, told the Evening Express: “There are problems in boardrooms with chairman and directors who don’t look at the bigger picture enough.“Billy McKinlay had one failed spell as a manager in Norway.“But ultimately he’s worked at the highest level with Real Sociedad, Fulham under Roy Hodgson and last season at West Ham, and David Moyes thinks the world of him.#What I know about Billy is that he’s a really good organiser of a team and from what I understand that’s what United need.“It’s not just because he’s an old team-mate but he’s somebody that’s dferent and I would like to see the people making the decision look at the bigger picture.”McInally, who played  times for United, is desperate to see his old clubto the Premiership.He added: “Their current plight has been down to lack of leadership at the top.#

title: neil mccann backs his dundee players to handle the heat
story: Dundee will have to face a dferent kind of pressure this weekend against Kilmarnock but manager Neil McCann is backing his players to handle it once again.The Dark Blues boss was full of praise for the way his defence dealt with Hamilton’s direct approach in the second half of their - victory.Accies brought on strikers Rakish Bingham and on-loan Mason Bloomfield as they bombarded the Dundee defensive line.However, with the help of the crossbar a couple of times, Dundee held out and lted some of the heat that’s been on the manager and his team after the six straight defeats that began their season.With Killie’s attacking line of Greg Stewart, Eamonn Brophy, Jordan Jones, Chris Burke and Kris Boyd it’ll be a dferent sort of pressure the Dark Blues will have to be ready to deal with.Neil, though, expects the edginess in their defending as they homed in on their first win to be gone come Saturday.He said: “The next game will be a tough one against Kilmarnock but we enjoyed last weekend because it had been a long time coming.“Against Hamilton, I knew they would go direct, they brought Bingham on and did go more direct.“You have to deal with that – there is only so much you can do as a manager, tactically, and the players have to deal with it.“You have to be able to deal with the threat of them going direct.“There was a wee bit of edge still in their game because I’ve been saying for weeks I’d love to see them go in front and see what it did to their game.“I always knew they would still be playing with pressure but they dealt with that.“They had to deal with long balls, there were a couple of balls flashed across the goal but I thought we were well worth our three points last Saturday.”Meanwhile, a Dundee reserve side including first-teamers Jack Hamilton, Darren O’Dea, Jesse Curran and Jean Mendy were thrashed - by Dunfermline at Kelty Hearts’ New Central Park.It was Jimmy Boyle’s men’s first defeat in the Reserve League with goals from Lewis McCann, two from former Dundee United man Robbie Muirhead and second-half penalties from Tom Beadling and Myles Hippolyte counting for the Pars.The match did see a first outing for new Dee signing Grant Nelson.The -year-old from Rangers signed up with Boyle’s reserve side before the contest.

title: paul quinn claims paul sturrocks role undermined csaba laszlo at dundee united
story: Former Dundee United defender Paul Quinn believes there have to be major changes at the clubthey are to progress.A policy was introduced in the summer to ensure new signings live within a -mile radius of the city but Quinn felt that was papering over the cracks.He said: “Dundee United fans have proved themselves to be good, loyal supporters over the years. They want the best for their club but when you are in Dundee getting moaned at from fans, I guess in restaurants etc, that’s not helpful to the players.“What they should try and change is Tannadice.“When you go in the door it needs modernised.“I love all their history. There are players there up on the wall who I couldn’t even begin to lace their boots. Even within the tunnel area, though, could there not be something changed to reflect the modern era “Something needs to change in the mental side of things to move Dundee United forward.”Quinn was surprised to see club legend Paul Sturrockto Tannadice in March as an adviser to Csaba Laszlo. He said: “Our manager is our leader – that’s the golden rule in football.“You give the gaffer everything but then somebody  comes in all of a sudden and immediately you think: ‘What’s going on here ’“Players talk as football is a small world. They think: ‘The manager likes me but do I now need to keep this new guy happy as well ’“I felt for Csaba then. There’s no way you can dispute what Luggy did as a player for United but that was back in the day.“It looked from the outside as though there was undermining going on – that’s just a fact.”

title: Fee introduction was a factor in recyling rate dip but just a blip insists Highland Council
story: THE controversial introduction of the fee for emptying brown bins was a factor in the arearsquos dip in recycling rates last year.But Highland Council chiefs say it was just a blip.While the level of household waste recycled nationally exceeded the amount sent to landfill for the first time, the tonnage slipped in Highland.The regionrsquos  recycling feat of . per cent dropped last year to . per cent ndash and last year a pound charge was brought in for emptying garden waste bins. This fee was increased to pound this year.The councilrsquos vice convener Allan Henderson, who also is also chairman of the environment committee, said: ldquoWhile wersquore getting better at recycling, the change to charging for brown bins has meant some garden waste being channelled into municipal waste.ldquoI believe our proposal to build a lsquomaterial recovery facilityrsquo and roll out extra brown bin coverage will reverse this slight dip.The latest figures from the Scottish Environment Protection Agencyshow that recycling rates improved at  of Scotlandrsquos  local authorities.It estimates that . per cent of waste generated in Scotland was recycled, which was an annual increase of . per cent.Scotlandrsquos environment secretary Roseanna Cunningham welcomed the figures but said more progress was needed, particularly in the cities.The biggest increases in recycling rates were in West Lothian, East Renfrewshire, Dumfries and Galloway, South Ayrshire and Aberdeen City.Ms Cunningham said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has big plans for tackling waste plastics, in particular by introducing a depositscheme, to further incentivise people to recycle.ldquoWersquove also introduced a household recycling charter for local authorities to sign up to, which is making the approach to recycling less confusing for households and creating a more consistent and efficient system for authorities.The Sepa figures show the amount of household waste generated in Scotland was . million tonnes in  ndash a decrease of , tonnes from .Friday  Oct  : PM

title: Gaelic centre plan has backing of Inverness public
story: A SURVEY has shown that there is signicant public support for a new Gaelic cultural centre in Inverness.The research, which was carried out by the Alba Heritage Trust with the aim of establishing the level of interest in a project celebrating Gaelic heritage, was met with ldquooverwhelming backing from members of the public.Alba Heritage Trust director Alastair Forbes says the reaction has from businesses and iniduals across the board has been signicant.ldquoWe are delighted to have had so many responses to the survey, he said.ldquoThe reaction from the public and private sectors and from members of the community for the establishment of a Gaelic cultural centre has been extremely positive which has given us great confidence in moving forward with the project.Dr Blackrsquos Memorial Hall in the city centre has already been earmarked as a potential venue for the initiative ndash backed by an architectural survey.Plans for potential facilities in the centre include a Gaelic cafeacute, a retail space selling Gaelic-themed products, and language classes as well as a cultural exhibition.It would also host ceilidhs, shows and performances, as well as talks and lectures on the subject of Gaelic culture.Alba Heritage Trust director Emily Macdonald said: ldquoA cultural centre of this type would be of great benefit to the city of Inverness and the wider Highland area.ldquoIt would provide a focal point for anyone with an interest in Gaelic language and culture.ldquoThe potential impacts include promoting Gaelic language and culture, increasing Gaelic usage, encouraging community interaction, attracting further cultural events to the city, creating jobs and enhancing Invernessrsquos offering as a centre for tourism.Friday  Oct  : PM

title: Highland Council shouldnt have to shoulder cost of Universal Credit introduction argues MP
story: Inverness and Nairn MP Drew Hendry is calling on the UK government to meet the additional burden and is also seeking an urgent meeting with Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey.It follows a similar demand from council leader Margaret Davidson who says the costs should not be met by Highland council tax and rent payers.Inverness was first chosen in  as the only place in Scotland to trial the much-criticised welfare reform which was implemented in the city two years ago and in the rest of the Highlands last year.Despite tales from claimants facing a tide of debt and dficulties ndash many of which were highlighted in the Inverness Courier ndash it is also being rolled out across the UK.But Mr Hendry described the move as ldquoshambolic and said people in the Highlands were having to subsidise the government for its failed project.ldquoDay in, day out, Highland Council staff have to deal with a system littered with inefficiencies and a host of process failures ndash costing not only more time for officers but lots more money from the councilrsquos budget, he said. ldquoIn addition to meeting administration costs, Highland Council is also having to burden the cost of rent arrears which have shot through the roof because of theof time people and landlords have to wait for payments. It simply cannot go on.According to figures obtained by Mr Hendry, the council spent pound, between - to administer universal credit but only received pound, from the government, leaving a gap of pound,.The figures also showed more than half the councilrsquos pound. million in rent arrears was directly attributable to the new system.Mr Hendry warned with nearly , people in the Highlands still to be transferred to universal credit the bill would continue to rise.Councillor Davidson also wrote to Ms McVey in August seeking full reimbursement of the costs but is still awaiting a reply.ldquoThe council continues to support claimants who are impacted by universal credit as a result of flaws in the system, Cllr Davidson said.But the councilrsquos Conservative leader Andrew Jarvie said lessons had been learned and issues ironed out.ldquoIt is easy to look at headline figures and see the situation gets blown out of all proportion, he said. ldquoPrior to universal credit, housing rent arrears were about pound million.A spokesman for the Department of Work and Pensions said support was provided for claimants as they moved to universal credit while a flexible payment system had been introduced in Scotland.ldquoRent arrears are complicated and they cannot be attributed to a single cause, he said. ldquoOur research shows that many people join universal credit with pre-existing arrears but the proportion of people with arrears falls by a third after four months on universal credit.-Drew Hendry will hold a welfare surgery on Friday for anyone struggling with benefit or welfare issues as part of the Poverty Alliancersquos Challenge Poverty Week.It will take place between noon and pm at Merkinch Community Centre.Other organisations taking part include Highland Council, Citizens Advice Bureau, Inverness Cathedral, Advocacy Highland, Employability Skills and Welfare Project, and MFR Cash for Kids.Friday  Oct  : PM

title: Inverness streets past preserved by key heritage trail
story: The new digital heritage trail, a key part of the Inverness Townscape Heritage Project, spent the past two-and-a-half years engaging with the community around Academy Street.During that time some  heritage lsquoengagement eventsrsquo were held and people were invited to share their stories.In the end more than  came forward, representing people such as A.
